But achieving the program’s goal of nourishing these food-insecure seniors is exceedingly challenging. When adjusted for inflation, the total amount of funding appropriated for nutrition services under the Older American Act has decreased substantially over the past two decades ($819.5 million for FY2010 compared to $941.7 million in FY1990). Add to that decreased private donations to supplement the programs, prohibitions against means testing and payment for nutrition services under Title III of the Older Americans Act (into which the program was incorporated in 1978), and the rapidly growing senior population, and it’s easy to see how programs dedicated to feeding seniors are potentially in danger. Interestingly, one of the greatest strains on the program may also turn out to be one of its biggest assets—the aging baby boomers, the first of whom turned 65 on January 1, 2011.  Some 10,000 more will turn 65 each day through 2029. By the time the last baby boomer turns 65, the population aged 65 and older will have doubled. Born between 1946 and 1964, the baby boomers are the largest, most vocal and most demanding generation in American history. They are also the wealthiest generation, controlling more than two-thirds of the nation’s assets. Projections from the Met Life Market Institute show that by the time the last boomer turns 65, the generation will control more than 40 percent of disposable income in the United States. Retirees could eventually control as much as $136 trillion. While clearly there will always be people who need subsidized nutrition services because they would otherwise go hungry, there will also be a significant number of seniors who can afford to pay for their food and additional conveniences.  Still others from this new “wealthy” segment of seniors will be able, and willing, to pay to get what they want, when they want it, the way they want it. To meet the future needs of the various types of consumers, providers of home and community-based meal services should run two parallel, yet synergistic, business models:  a non-profit program for low-income or means-tested customers, which would continue to be funded by state and federal dollars and private donations, and a for-profit operation that would be paid for by the consumers themselves.  The latter could perhaps supplement funding for the non-profit program for those seniors who are unable to pay or are paying on a sliding scale according to their income level. While many aspects of this report will touch on all three groups of clients – those who cannot pay, those who can afford to pay for some extra conveniences, and those able and willing to pay a premium for special foods and services – the unpredictability of federal funding prompts us to focus largely on the third, more affluent group, who hold the power to help financially support these services for seniors across the board. To serve the more affluent boomers, home and community based service providers will have to make significant changes to a program that has changed little since 1972. Just like the leisure suit has gone out of style, so has the traditional senior center, serving up a rubber chicken and congealed salad lunch followed by Bingo or a bridge game. To attract tomorrow’s seniors, the traditional senior center will have to appeal to a more active, demanding clientele, by offering a variety of food choices as well as activities ranging from videography to dating services, all in a more attractive upscale environment. Similarly meal delivery services will need to make changes to serve the varied nutritional needs and tastes of the aging baby boomers. This may include pre-cut foods for seniors with limited manual dexterity, foods for special diets (low-sodium, low-cholesterol, low-carbohydrate), spicier foods to tempt aging taste buds and ethnic dishes for consumers of different cultural groups.   For baby boomers who can afford higher-end menu offerings, the ability to get quality, healthful foods conveniently will mean more than just cost. Witness the success of Whole Foods Market, an Austin, Texas-based grocer specializing in natural and organic foods.   When the recession squelched spending on indulges such as its expensive chocolates and cheeses, Whole Foods Market shifted its focus back to its natural and organic roots, with highly profitable results. In the most recent quarter, the company reported earnings of $57 million, or 33 cents a share, up from $36 million, or 20 cents a share, a year earlier. The chain is now making changes for convenience, adding healthier prepared foods and baked goods in stores nationwide that meet new criteria such as sprouted grain bread with no refined flour, added oil, refined sugar or processed ingredients. With some strategic planning, HCBS providers should have a similarly profitable program. Targeted at upscale consumers, the program could also potentially supplement funding to meet the goals established for elderly nutrition programs in 1972. While there are a myriad of trends associated with the baby boomer generation, this report examines the critical directives needed to properly transform home and community based meal programs to efficiently serve all mature adults who are seeking socialization, independence and proper nutrition.  The dozen transformational concepts that follow represent a paradigm shift and the adoption of alternative thinking in an attempt to create a less stagnate nutrition program for our nation’s older adults, regardless of income level, ethnicity, health concerns or special dietary needs. 1.  Follow Population Trends.  The 65-plus population is expected to grow by 36 percent overall between 2010 and 2020, with some areas experiencing higher percentages of growth than others. Thus, the prospect of serving the greatest number of seniors, and consequently creating increased revenue opportunities, will require directing services to areas expected to experience the highest amount of growth. With the recession and housing crisis slowing migration between states and cities, more boomers are aging in place than in past decades. This means that areas that have experienced the highest increase in the baby boomer population in recent years will likely be the same ones experiencing the greatest growth in the senior population tomorrow. For example, the Urban Institute -- a Washington, D.C.-based think tank that conducts research, and educates Americans on social and economic issues– predicts that Georgia’s senior population will increase by 40 percent between 2010 and 2020 due to the aging of baby boomers. On the other hand, Florida -- which has long been a haven for seniors from the cold northern states -- will likely experience slowed growth as fewer people flee large cities such as New York and Chicago.  Thus the greatest demand for services for seniors tomorrow may not be the same as in past years or today. According to an analysis by the Brookings Institute, a nonprofit public policy organization based in Washington, D.C., the following metropolitan areas experienced the greatest gains in the 55 to 64 population between 2000 and 2007 and will likely experience the highest rate of growth in seniors in the decade ahead due to the aging of the baby boomers. As a result, these 20 areas represent prime markets for ramping up senior home delivery and congregate nutrition services.
  • Raleigh-Carey, N.C. (31.6 percent increase between 2000 and 2007).
  • Austin-Round Rock, Texas (30.1 percent increase between 2000 and 2007)
  • Atlanta- Sandy Springs- Marietta, Ga. (29.8 percent increase between 2000 and 2007)
  • Boise City-Nampa, Idaho (28.7 percent increase between 2000 and 2007)
  • Las Vegas-Paradise, Nev. (27.8 percent increase between 2000 and 2007)
Others rounding out the top 20 are: Orlando-Kissimmee, Fla.; Houston-Sugar Land- Baytown, Texas; Dallas-Fort Worth-Arlington, Texas; Colorado Springs, Colo.; McAllen-Edinburg-Mission, Texas; Phoenix-Mesa-Scottsdale, Ariz.; Charleston-North Charleston, S.C.;  Albuquerque, N.M.; Tucson, Ariz.; Washington, D.C. -Arlington-Alexandria, Va.;  Salt Lake City, Utah; Charlotte-Gastonia-Concord, N.C.-S.C. ; Denver-Aurora, Colo.; Nashville-Davidson-Murphreesboro-Franklin, Tenn.; Ogden-Clearfield-Utah. 2.  Update the Image. Much like the homes of deserving families selected for renovation on the popular TV series, home and community services are in need of an extreme makeover. Home delivery and congregate dining services tend to have a stigma attached to them due to the long-standing circulation of misinformation widely disseminated both externally and within the HCBS industry.  A recent survey conducted by Bateman Senior Meals, a division of the Compass Group, indicated that ___ percent of their meal recipients stated that they feel home delivery and congregate feeding is perceived as being strictly for ”low income” participants. The Meals On Wheels Association of America, formed in 1976, has reportedly struggled in recent years with the perception of being strictly a poverty or government-funded program, neither of which is true. Some clients have supposedly asked drivers to remove Meals On Wheels signage from their vehicles before entering their neighborhoods in an effort to reduce the “embarrassment factor” associated with receiving a free meal; others have refused the service entirely, believing that by accepting the meal they are depriving someone else who needs it more than they do. According to Peggy Ingraham, MOWAA Senior Vice President for Public Policy, Meals On Wheels provides nutrition to seniors regardless of their income, and is not strictly a government program.  In fact, of the 5,000 senior nutrition programs across the country, only 3,000 receive any type of state or federal funding, yet, Ingraham reports, its perception as a government program at times interferes with Meals On Wheels’ ability to get private funding, Updating the current image of home and community based services, such as Meals On Wheels, might involve a name and logo change, a move several nonprofits have taken in recent years. Most recently the Young Men’s Christian Association (YMCA) became simply “The Y” to align with how most people commonly refer to the organization. The organization also unveiled a new logo — the first logo change since 1967 – “to better reflect the vibrancy of the Y and the diversity of the communities it serves,“ according to the organization.  A decade ago, the American Association of Retired People dropped its formal name to become AARP, doing away with the word “retired,” which research indicated was increasingly irrelevant to its current and potential membership. A new name and updated image will bring new life and a brand extension to meal delivery services and attract a whole new clientele, including customers who are able and willing to pay for meals and other services. 3.   Serve More Than Meals.  Bundling services, which has proven successful for Internet providers, can also provide new revenue opportunities for home-based meal delivery companies and offer a much-needed service for the seniors they serve. While homebound seniors need nutritious food, they also need paper goods, medications, toiletries, etc.. As recent business models have shown, people like to have – and are willing to pay a premium for – books, videos and other items to be delivered directly to their homes.  One example is the Atlanta-based Zifty.com, which advertises it will deliver “everything from DVD rentals, games, food, and more to you in about an hour or less.” Among seniors surveyed by Bateman Senior Meals___ percent indicated that they would want the option to pay for additional services similar those offered by Zifty.com. Anticipating the additional needs homebound seniors might require, meal delivery organizations should make available supplementary services that are not currently being provided. For those needing assistance with minor household chores, the bundle could include 10 or 15 minutes of the driver’s time for simple tasks such as replacing a burnt-out light bulb, moving a piece of furniture, loosening child-proof tops on medicine bottles, washing a sink full of dishes, starting a load of laundry, moving items from a high shelf to a lower one, or sweeping the front porch steps.  The driver could also deliver certain items that are requested such as prescription medication, grocery items, stamps, etc. While bundling services may not be plausible for the low-income model, it could offer a potential source of revenue for the provider and a needed service for means-tested and private-pay clients. Serving “more than meals” is also a good strategy for congregate dining centers, which have seen declining numbers of clients over the past two decades. Between 1990 and 2008, the number of congregate meals served through the elderly nutrition program dropped by 34 percent, while the number of home-delivered meals grew by 44 percent. Experts attribute the decrease in congregate dining to a number of possible factors, including the trend by states to transfer funds from their congregate service allotments to home-delivered services, and greater growth in home-delivered services relative to the congregate program funds.  Magi Brettler, Regional Vice President at Bateman Senior Meals, suggests the negative perception of congregate dining centers also may play a role in the decline. “People avoid them because they don't want to be seen in a poverty program if they have money,” she says. Regardless of the reason for the shift, congregate dining offers benefits – primarily companionship and connectedness – for mobile seniors that meal delivery services cannot, and efforts to boost that component of food services is crucial. For seniors who have their meals in congregate dining locations, adding more creative options would add more value. It might also draw in more clients.  Helpful services might include a small library where individuals could swap books, medication delivery to the site so seniors could pick up their prescriptions, the services of a registered dietitian to offer dietary planning, and on-site tax preparation services each year at tax time. But to draw in significantly more clients or bring them in more frequently, organizations must consider the wants and interests of mature adults, who, as a whole, are living longer and in better health than at any time in history and want to feel engaged and connected. Such services might include memoir writing and videography classes, free wi-fi or Internet cafes, gyms or weight rooms with the optional services of a physical therapist or a physical trainer, or even an on-site dating or matchmaking service for widows and widowers. Taking a more active role in the enhancement of the center would be a wise investment by a food services provider, when food alone isn’t attracting the optimal number of clients.  Enhancing the center could mean more than adding additional services. It might also mean changing the location and upgrading the environment where meals are offered and the times they are available.  For example, physically moving dining centers from places like church basements or government buildings to malls or shopping centers alongside Starbuck’s or Einstein Bagels would enhance the availability and aesthetics of the dining experience. Having them operate the same hours as nearby shops would allow seniors to stop in for a hot lunch or a nutritious snack or to visit with friends after shopping or mall walking. Enhancing centers could also include updating the image with more attractive décor, inviting exteriors and even a more appealing name to attract a new generation of seniors who may be put off by names like community center, senior center or congregate dining center. In Chicago, examples of new senior centers can be seen at cafes operated by Mather Lifeways, a non-for-profit service agency. The cafes, located in working-class neighborhoods, attract younger (55 and up) and older seniors alike, who come to enjoy a cup of coffee or lunch. With their open kitchens, bright colors, floating ceiling panels and modern light fixtures, the cafes scarcely resemble your grandmother’s senior center. 4.  Provide Companionship. While some seniors would prefer to have add-on services bundled with their meal delivery, for others the most valuable supplementary service would be a longer visit with their delivery person.  Interestingly, the recent Bateman Senior Meals survey indicated that ___ percent of respondents ranked spending time with the person delivering the food as being more important than the price or timing of their meal delivery. Twenty-eight percent of Americans over the age of 65 live alone. For those over age 85, that increases to 48 percent. Increasing time between scheduled deliveries would allow drivers to spend more time with seniors who live alone and often long for companionship. Older adults who are homebound due to health problems or mobility limitations are often isolated and at risk for loneliness and depression.  In a given year, between 1 and 2 percent of people over age 65 suffer from major depression, meaning that intense sadness or the absence of pleasure or the ability to experience it disrupts social functioning and activities of daily living. About 2 percent have dysthymia – a less severe but long-lasting lack of enjoyment or pleasure in life that in some cases also affects daily functioning and sleep – and, according to the National Institute of Mental Health, up to a fourth or more have subclinical depression that does not meet the criteria for depression but nonetheless is associated with increased risk of depression, physical disability, medical illness and high use of health services. Research has also found a significant association between social isolation and negative health outcomes. Individuals who lack social connections or report frequent feelings of loneliness are more likely to suffer higher rates of illness, death, infection and cognitive decline. According to “Social Isolation: Strategies for Connecting and Engaging Older People,” a report by the Cornell Institute for Translational Research on Aging, people living below the poverty line are at particular risk of social isolation. Of all seniors living alone and below the poverty line, one-third go as long as two weeks at a time without seeing friends or neighbors; one-fifth have no phone conversations with friends or family. Thus, for many housebound seniors, the contact with a person delivering their meals may be the only human contact they have some days or even weeks. Even a 15-minute visit would provide a welcome reprieve from the loneliness and isolation these mature adults experience. Whether it’s spent sitting down to look through old photo albums, listening to stories about their grandchildren or just talking about the weather, a delivery person’s time and attention is the most welcome service many seniors could receive. For older adults who are able to get out, community dining offers similar benefits of companionship. Enjoying a meal and conversation with others reduces isolation that has become increasingly common as families have become smaller and often spread out geographically.  Seniors are also likely to eat more in the company of others, therefore nutrition may be improved. Such add-on services will also offer much needed respite for primary caregivers who have seniors they are caring that live close by. Relieving the caregiver from being the sole source of help and companionship for their aging loved one will reduce the stress very often associated with the role of caregiving, which has been shown to take a toll on the caregiver’s emotional and physical health. An estimated 20 percent of family caregivers suffer from depression – about twice that of the general population. For long distance caregivers, knowing that someone regularly sees and spends time with their aging loved one can provide a high level of comfort and help alleviate concerns about their loved ones safety and security. 5.  Co-Brand with a Membership Only Club. In an effort to significantly increase revenue and the current client base at congregate dining centers - and help ensure mature adults frequent return – it would be wise to operate dining centers in areas where senior-oriented health clubs are already positioned. Research shows that baby boomers make up the fastest growing segment of health club membership.  People over 55 now represent nearly a quarter of all health club members, according to the International Health, Racquet and Sportsclub Association.  Joining forces with “senior clubs” would give seniors a place to dine and work out side-by-side with other seniors – not hard-bodied twenty-somethings – in classes designed to improve balance, strengthen fragile bones, increase joint range of motion and maintain functional ability, all of which are of special concern to seniors. Much like the Y, senior centers could offer different levels of membership. For a basic fee, the member would have access to the gym and café during all open hours and could participate in classes or other activities for an additional cost. For a higher fee, members would not only have full access to the gym, but could take classes at a discount or no additional charge. Premium members might also receive other perks (free or discounted tickets for the theater, sporting events, municipal golf courses or hair salons; upgraded meals, branded workout gear; access to a personal trainer, for example) that are not offered members paying the basic member fee. Also, as is the case in many private health clubs, reciprocal memberships could be extended to clubs in other cities and states so that seniors could workout, attend a class or have a meal while traveling or staying with family in another town. Managed much like the “senior club” concept, the North Shore Senior Center serves 32 Chicago suburbs, from Evanston to Highland Park, operating from a vast 40,000-square-foot building. Members pay a $60 annual membership fee and the center includes a fitness center, sculpture studio, café, classrooms and a sunny atrium.  With 4,000 members and 700 volunteers, North Shore gets $1 million a year from donors and raised $15 million more in a capital campaign for the new building. One way North Shore cultivates relationships with the “young-old” is by helping them care for elderly parents, with a daughters support group and geriatric case managers. Another attraction is the fitness center — members pay $350 extra — where fliers advertise boomer-friendly “brain fitness” classes for the worried well and a conference on female spirituality. By operating within an established club, congregate dining centers would give seniors a sense of belonging and – with membership perks – more value for their dollar. Paying dues would also increase the likelihood that mature adults would return often, wanting to make the most of their investment. 6. Cater to Aging Taste Buds.  We are born with 9,000 or 10,000 taste buds on our tongues as well as on the sides and roof of the mouth, but around age 40 to 50 in women and 50 to 60 in men the number of taste buds begins to decrease and the remaining taste buds start to atrophy and become less sensitive. Similar age-related changes in the sense of smell – which plays a major role in what we perceive as taste – as well as illnesses, smoking or a lifelong accumulation of environmental exposures can amplify the problem. Aging’s effects on the ability to taste – along with the growing popularity of ethnic foods and the desire for low-fat, low-salt seasonings – is prompting tomorrow's seniors to seek out bolder, spicier foods. The demand for spicy foods is evidenced by the plethora of ethnic restaurants and high-octane offerings at chain restaurants including McDonald's Chipotle BBQ Snack Wrap and T.G.I. Friday's Wicked Wings, as well as a growing list of spicy snack foods on supermarket shelves, including Spicy Guacamole Pringles and Flamin' Hot Cheetos. Older adults also prefer boldly flavored cheeses, such as bleu, feta and Gorgonzola, according to Sloan Trends, Inc., an Escondido, Calif., firm that tracks behavioral and consumer habits in food and nutrition. Food manufacturers have found that making food more palatable to aging boomers goes beyond enhancing the taste, but also the texture and color of the food. For example, research has shown that the color red enhances food's acceptability among the baby boomer age group. Food with more texture can also heighten taste. ____percent of those who responded to the Bateman Senior Services survey reported that they felt that by adding sauces or spices it would greatly improve the flavor of the prepared food that they were being served. To improve food flavor – and consumption – and increase brand recognition, food service providers should try what barbecue restaurants and Mexican restaurants have done for years:  offer branded sauces and seasonings of different heat levels (think mild to el scorcho) that can be added at the table. Offering seasonings as an option – either on the table or in packets delivered with meals – allows customers to season foods to their personal taste and helps prevent over-seasoning for seniors with health conditions such as gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), peptic ulcer disease, diverticulitis or inflammatory bowel disease that are often exacerbated by spicy or highly seasoned foods. 7. Offer Variety and Convenience.   Raised in an era where regularly eating out became commonplace, ice cream shops offered 31 flavors, and fast food restaurants promised that you can “have it your way,” baby boomers are used to choosing from a variety of foods prepared to their own specification – and quickly. A 2009 survey by Cornell University Center for Hospitality Research found that adults age 55 and older eat out an average of 51 times a year, and roughly half of the 20 most popular restaurants among the 55-plus age group are fast food chains, including Wendy’s KFC, Burger King, Taco Bell, Dairy Queen, Panda Express and McDonald’s. To lure customers from fast food and casual dining establishments, congregate dining centers must offer more food options and make it easier for customers to get them. ___ percent of Bateman survey respondents said that they would be willing to pay extra for more increased food variety, and ___ percent said they would be willing to pay more for a specific type of beverage if it were served with their meal. For delivery programs, seniors could be a given a menu of items from which to choose for the week.  In fact __ percent of survey respondents said they would be willing to pay an additional fee for this add-on.  At congregate dining centers variety and choice should be emphasized in a cafeteria, deli or even a food-court setting, with different stations offering different food choices (salad, sandwiches, Asian food, Mexican foods, frozen yogurt and desserts). Rather than everyone sitting down to an identical meal, seniors could mix and match their own favorite a` la carte dishes to create a nutritionally balanced meal, whether it be meatloaf with mashed potatoes and green beans or seafood burritos with a Caesar salad. Steps to increase convenience could include techniques used by chain restaurants including drive-thru service; phone-ahead and online ordering with curbside service or designated parking places for customers picking up phone or Internet orders; and even money-saving coupons distributed by direct mail, newspapers with high senior readership, organizations such as AARP or websites that cater to baby boomers and seniors.   Adopting these techniques, which have led to success for so many of their favorite restaurants, would enable to seniors to get the foods they want when they want them and perhaps the satisfaction of saving a little time in the process. 8.  Acknowledge Ethnic Diversity.  The seniors of today – and even more so tomorrow – are an ethnically diverse group.  While the media tends to routinely portray baby boomers as white, in fact 12 percent are African-American, 9 percent are Hispanic, 4 percent are Asian or Pacific Islander, and a bit less than 1 percent are Native American or Native Alaskan. By the middle of this century, the percentage of African-American seniors is projected increase from 8 to 10 percent of Americans over age 65.  The Hispanic population, which currently represents fewer than 4 percent of older people in the U.S., is projected to represent nearly 16 percent of older adults by mid-century. To succeed at serving this diverse senior population today and particularly in the coming decades, nutrition programs must embrace their clients’ diversity. Serving familiar ethnic foods at congregate meal sites and through home delivery services will increase the likelihood that clients will eat – and enjoy – their meals. Serving ethnic foods may also be a way to increase participation – and revenue – at congregate dining centers by baby boomers as a whole, whose tastes have been shaped by diversity. ___ percent of Bateman Senior Services survey respondents said they would be willing to pay extra for ethnic dishes. When designing menus, meal service providers need to consider the cultural food preferences for all participants, looking at the population make-up of the area they are serving – for example, cites like Honolulu; Bellview, Washington; Sugar Land, Texas; and Holmdel Township, N.J, where the Chinese-American population is higher than 10 percent; or cities like Chamblee, Georgia; Hialeah, Florida; Minidoka, Idaho; Reading, Pennsylvania; Douglas, Arizona; and Pasco, Washington, where more than half – and, in some cases, close to 90 percent – of the population is Hispanic. While dishes like spaghetti with garlic bread, and beef and broccoli are staples of many nutrition programs, providers should consider adding less common choices gained from other cultures, particularly for customers willing to pay a premium for ethnic dishes. In particular, serving the nation’s burgeoning Hispanic population – which the Census Bureau projects will constitute nearly 30 percent of the U.S. population, or 132.8 million people, by the year 2050 -- presents a particular challenge, but also a potentially profitable opportunity for food service providers. Depending on their country of origin, Hispanic Americans face a greater risk of certain health conditions, including obesity and diet-mediated problems such as high blood pressure, high cholesterol and diabetes.  For example, almost half of Hispanics over age 65 have high blood pressure, according to the National Institutes of Health, and close to half of Hispanic-American adults as a whole have high or borderline high total cholesterol levels. About 10.2 percent of all Hispanic Americans have diabetes – almost double the rate for non-Hispanic whites of similar age. Furthermore, Hispanic Americans who have diabetes are more likely to suffer end-stage kidney disease as a result, and are 50 percent more likely than non-Hispanic whites to die from diabetes-related complications. Clearly, providing healthy and palatable food choices for this vulnerable and growing population should be one of the focuses of any nutrition program during the coming decades.  Although the food industry has made significant progress in developing healthy and functional foods for Hispanic consumers in recent years, according to Nerac, a Connecticut-based research firm dedicated to developing innovative products and technologies, the Hispanic market represents an undeveloped arena to promote lighter and healthier Latin American fare. 9.  Accommodate Health Needs. Thanks to improved nutrition and life-saving medical advances – antibiotics, vaccines,  heart surgery, blood thinners, improvements in cancer diagnosis and treatment, and the near eradication of infectious diseases such as tuberculosis, just to name a few – seniors in America are living much longer than their parents and grandparents. According to the Social Security Administration, the life expectancy of a 50-year-old man today is 79.4; for a 50-year-old woman life expectancy is 81.6, and life expectancy increases as one ages. A male who reaches age 65 can expect to live another 16 years, on average, to age 81. A woman who reaches 65 can expect to live another 19 years, to age 84.   But living longer often means living with chronic diseases, or diseases that often last the rest of one’s life and can affect quality of life – and nutritional needs.  According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, eight out of 10 Americans age 65 and older are living with some form of chronic illness. Common chronic illnesses such as heart disease, diabetes, kidney disease and arthritis are likely to not only influence dietary needs (for example, low-sodium, low-fat, low-carbohydrate), but also the need for special packaging and food preparation. For example, data from 2007 to 2009 show that 49.9 million American adults have self-reported, doctor-diagnosed arthritis. By 2020 an estimated 59.9 million – a large percentage of whom will be seniors – will have arthritis, according to the Arthritis Foundation and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Although it is not a disease directly affected by nutrition, arthritis can make it difficult for many people to get the proper nutrition they need. Arthritis in the hips and knees makes it difficult to stand and prepare foods. Arthritis in the jaw can make chewing difficult. Arthritis that affects the fingers and small joints of the hands, which is very common, can affect manual dexterity, making it difficult to open food packages and cut foods. Thus, easy-to-open packages, soft foods and food prepared in bite-size servings such as stews or casseroles, will well serve seniors, who may forgo a meal if they have difficulty opening the package or cutting the food into sizes they can eat. It is also a superb service for long-distance caregivers who are not available to help their aging loved one at meal time and will enable seniors with dexterity problems to stay independent longer. A recent survey conducted by Bateman Senior Services resulted in end users reporting that ___ percent would be willing to pay extra for special meals, such as low-sodium (__percent), low-fat ( ___ percent), and low-carbohydrate (__ percent). ___ percent ranked easy-to-open-packages highest in importance, above _____ and ____ (Again, this is a case where items are ranked, so we’ll have to see how this ranks with respondents.) 10.  Form Creative Collaborations.  While the recession means fewer baby boomers are relocating upon retirement, it also means more grown children and grandchildren are moving in with their aging parents. According to AARP, more than six million children under 18 in America are living in a grandparent-headed household, which is a daunting challenge to the aging population. Among the issues these grandparents face are advanced aging and decreased energy, financial difficulties, caregiver burnout, the need for support wherever possible, and – according to a groundbreaking research study conducted by Meals On Wheels Association of America Foundation (MOWAAF) -- increased risk of hunger. “The Causes, Consequences, and Future of Single Hunger in America” by MOWAAF found living with a grandchild to be an unexpected and significant predictor of hunger risk among seniors. Seniors with a grandchild in the home – regardless of whether the child’s parent(s) also lived there – were about 50 percent more likely to be at risk of hunger compared to those with no grandchild in the home. The increase in intergenerational living – and risks associated with it – clearly presents special challenges for senior nutrition services. Yet, at the same time it may offer opportunities for partnerships with other organizations, programs and even private businesses that don’t immediately come to mind when thinking of feeding the elderly. In 2006, an innovative partnership between MOWAA and Banfield, The Pet Hospital, resulted in the “Seasons of Supper Campaign” an annual fundraising event designed to ensure that seniors’ furry companions are healthy and well fed and that seniors’ nutrition isn’t compromised by sharing their food with their pets.  The Banfield Charitable Trust recognizes the importance of the bond between seniors and their pets throughout the year by funding pet food distributions across the country. The success of the program, which involves 750 Banfield locations nationwide, only hints at how positive the reception would be for a partnership that funds meals for grandparents and their grandchildren.  Examples of potential partners to assist grandparent-headed families include:
  • Women, Infants, and Children (WIC) – a federal program serving low-income mothers and their children through age 5
  • Gerber, Beech-Nut and Heinz baby food manufacturers
  • Day care chains
  • The Boys & Girls Club
  • Big Brothers Big Sisters
  • Diaper delivery services
  • Tutoring services
Pooling resources makes sense at a time when donor dollars are down, gas prices are rising, volunteers are often in short supply, and the baby boomers, who for years have been the major source of revenue and provision of such programs, will be the ones requiring them. 11.  Let the Customer Be the Chef. If their interest in TV cooking shows is any indication, many baby boomers and older adults enjoy cooking in their own kitchens! A recent Harris Poll showed over half (55 percent) of Baby Boomers and almost half (49 percent) of adults over age 65 watch cooking shows often or occasionally.  More than half of those who watch cooking shows say they have purchased food as a direct result of something they have seen on a show and more than one- third have purchased kitchen gadgets. Baby boomers are more likely than other age groups to have made these purchases, with 60 percent purchasing food and 41 percent buying kitchen gadgets. More than just the “title” of a book that taught baby boomers and their mothers to cook, the joy of cooking is a key reason behind the popularity of cooking shows as well as cooking schools and restaurants where customers become chefs.   From casual steakhouses where diners grill their own meat to upscale restaurants like Chicago’s Cook Au Vin or Flat Top Grill where patrons prepare and eat their own traditional French dishes or Asian Fusion feasts, an increasing number of restaurants are offering customers the opportunity to prepare and cook their own meals. Rather than a chore to be completed, many baby boomers and seniors view cooking as way to express their creativity and ensure they are getting fresh, nutritious foods.  Thus, given the choice, some may very well choose the delivery of fresh ingredients and easy recipes rather than meals that are prepared for them in advance. For seniors who are cognitively able to follow recipes and use electrical appliances, giving them the opportunity to prepare their own meals – from ingredients already organized in advance in an effort to minimize cutting, chopping and measuring -- can offer a sense of independence and achievement. Catering to this same “do-it-yourself” attitude may also be an option for congregate dining centers, whether that means offering something as simple as a salad bar or taco bar, where clients can build their own meals or providing fresh ingredients that seniors can take home to prepare their own meals. In the case of the latter scenario, the food service provider could choose several recipes and offer ingredients to mature adults, allowing them to prepare those dishes on-site.  In addition, clients should be given the opportunity to share recipes and ideas with other congregate dining customers, fostering both independence and social interaction, two facets that are often lacking in seniors lives. Taking this a step further, a food service provider could work with congregate dining centers to offer cooking classes, which might rekindle the joy of cooking for widows, who once enjoyed and took pride in cooking for their families.  Classes could focus on simple “single-serving” meals or “several-portion” dishes that freeze well. After class, clients would have the opportunity to sit down with one another and enjoy the meal they prepared together Cooking classes also open the door to other partnerships – for example, with television cooking shows and celebrity chefs.  Perhaps cooking programs could provide “senior-friendly” recipes or donate a percentage of sales from cookbooks or product sales to eliminate senior hunger.  Cooking programs might begin to occasionally feature cooking- for-one or cooking-for-seniors segments and inform food service providers in advance of menus and ingredient lists, so that seniors who watch the program could have that week’s ingredients – and quite possibly any gadgets used in preparing the meal – delivered to their home. 12.  Going Green – and Organic. Whether they’re buying organic foods or recycling aluminum cans and newspapers, baby boomers are not only interested in what goes into their own bodies – but into the environment as well.  A recent survey by Harris Interactive found that baby boomers and older Americans are more likely to recycle than adults 30 and younger. The 62-plus age group leads all other segments of the population with 81 percent having reported that they regularly recycle something in their home, be it aluminum cans, paper, glass or plastic. According to “Shopping for Health,” a report by the Food Marketing Institute (FMI) and Prevention magazine, younger baby boomers lead all other age groups in the purchase of organic foods, with 57 percent of them buying organic foods regularly. A 2010 survey by Harris Interactive found that 27 percent of baby boomers say that more than a quarter of their grocery purchases are organic. This marks a 7 percent increase from 2009. The Shopping for Health report also cites the growing demand for foods that are both healthful and environmentally friendly as key drivers of organic food sales.  More than eight in ten (81 percent) people who purchase organic foods regularly indicated they do so for their nutritional value; 77 percent cite freshness as a reason for purchasing organic foods and 67 percent mention a desire to promote long-term health.  Furthermore, many believe that organic foods just taste better!  In fact, ___ percent of Bateman Senior Meals survey respondents stated that they believed adding organic food choices would improve the taste and nutritional value of their meals Because of the volume of food and packaging, and the resources used to prepare and deliver food, a food service company that serves organic foods and uses environmentally friendly practices could make a positive impact on the environment and position itself as a leader in this area. In addition, a number of organizations offer a “Green Seal of Approval” for businesses that meet certain criteria in promoting environmental sustainability. Three of the most prestigious are the Green Seal Certification awarded by Green Seal,  a non-profit organization that uses science-based programs to empower consumers, purchasers and companies to create a more sustainable world; Green America’s Business Seal of Approval,  awarded by Green America, a nonprofit membership organization dedicated to harnessing the economic power of consumers, investors and businesses to promote social justice and environmental sustainability; and the Good Housekeeping’s Green Seal. Examples of potential environmentally-friendly practices within the HCBS industry might include:
  • Using hybrid vehicles for meal deliveries
  • Packaging meals in recycled and recyclable materials that would be returned to the driver or placed in prominently marked receptacles at congregate dining centers
  • Creating gardens on the grounds of community centers where clients could grow fruits, vegetables and herbs - using the food they grow as ingredients in the meals served and table scraps for mulch.
Meals on Wheels of Central Maryland is already taking steps to go green by implementing its Green Building Project, designed to reduce energy consumption so that future savings to the organization’s operating budget can be directed toward increased meal production and delivery costs to serve an anticipated growth in the number of their projected homebound clients by 2020. Adoption of such programs and practices by other meal service providers would demonstrate that their organizations are not only concerned with containing costs to serve more seniors, but also with preserving the earth’s resources for generations to come. What’s ahead? Like leisure suits and rotary phones, the nutrition program of our grandparents’ day has become passé.  As the grandchildren of the program’s original clients approach retirement age themselves and the explosion of the senior population is imminent, it’s crucial that home and community based meal service providers take steps to both address the vulnerabilities of this growing market and capitalize on its strengths. Home and community based meal service providers must take into account the differences that exist within the various segments and cohorts of our senior adult population – including ethnicity, dietary needs, interests and income levels. By doing so, they can develop a parallel line of programs with diverse offerings that provide what essentially all mature adults want and deserve: nutritious, appetizing food served by someone who cares -- and perhaps a little fun!
column17: baby boomers|bateman senior|bateman senior meals|congregate dining|congregate dining centers|dining centers|food|foods|home and community|increase between 2000 and 2007|meal|meal service providers|meals|meals on wheels|organic foods|senior|seniors|service providers|services|willing to pay

column2: Getting Well Without the Wait
Save Big – Just by Being a Senior
column3:
I recently wrote a blog about great senior discounts and it was met with overwhelming interest and response!  But there are many other areas where seniors need not spend more. In fact, thousands of establishments across the U.S. will give you bargains on goods and services simply for meeting a certain age milestone – usually 55, 60 or 65, but in some cases as early as 50. Wondering what all you can get at a discount?  Here is just a sample of the bargains available for the asking. Travel – Finally have time to travel? From transportation to lodging, trips can become more affordable with senior discounts. Here is a list of the airlines taht will currently you incentives to fly (since everyone asks about travel discounts this section is the focus!):
  • Air France: Senior fares are reserved for passengers 60 years of age or older within metropolitan France. Proof of age must be shown, and these tickets may be changed at no charge or refunded in certain conditions. They can be reached at 1-800-237-2747.
  • American Airlines: Senior citizen fares are offered in some American, American Eagle and American Connection domestic markets for seniors ages 65 or older. Travelers should call American Airlines at 1-800-433-7300.
  • Delta: While offering senior discounts on certain itineraries, they aren’t available online, so travelers should call 1-800-221-1212 to check eligibility.
  • Delta Shuttle: Senior fares are offered for travelers ages 62 and above. Delta Shuttle operates 16 daily flights between New York and Boston, and 15 daily flights between New York and Washington, D.C., Monday through Friday. Call reservations at 800-221-1212 and tell the agent that you are interested in the senior fares or check with an agent at any Delta ticket office.
  • Southwest Airlines: Discount fares are available to those 65 years or older. For details on fares and limitations, call 1-800-I-FLY-SWA (1-800-435-9792). As an additional benefit, senior fares are also fully refundable on Southwest.
  • United Airlines: United offers senior citizen discounts in certain markets. Contact United’s reservations department at 1-800-241-6522 to find out if a senior discount is applicable for a particular flight.
Some airlines don’t offer discounts on flights, but have partnership agreements offering senior discounts on hotels, rental cars, and attractions and events. Organizations like AARP have an active discount travel program that covers car rentals, hotels, tours, and cruises, so check them out before booking.   Even if you don’t see what you’re looking for here, find what you want and then ask about a discount. Senior discounts have become so common that it never hurts to ask for one – whether the establishment you visit promotes one or not. Most places will take your word for it if you say you’re a senior, but carry along your picture ID and AARP card, if you have one, just in case. You never know what bargain treasures await you just for the number of candles on your birthday cake!

column2: The Week: Live to 150 (Very Funny!)
column3: LAST WEEK'S CONTEST: Scientists are working to slow the aging process, raising the possibility that we could someday live to be 150. What’s one reason we should NOT want to live that long? THE WINNER: We would have to wait until we were 75 to have a midlife crisis Jonathan Lubow, Randolph, N.J. SECOND PLACE: Faded, sagging tattoos Dawn Thaman, Cincinnati THIRD PLACE: That’s how many election cycles!? Joseph Smith, Huntersville, N.C.

column2: Menopause & Exercise: Dr. A Q&A
column3: Although I have yet to experience "the change of life" myself (it's knocking on the door!!!)...as a Gerontologist I'm very often asked about it and most commonly whether exercise will help make the journey just a little bit easier! In my opinion (and many others) exercise is a natural elixir for most physical (and many emotional) challenges women face. I recently read a great article by Peter Ragnar that asks the question: "Is exercise an elixir that can add years to your life and life to your years?"....Peter cites interesting research throughout the article that certainly endorses this theory. Menopause can be a difficult time in a woman's life - both emotionally and physically. Fortunately, a program consisting of regular exercise can help enhance your life and improve your overall well-being. In fact, lots of credible research has been conducted with findings that firmly support the idea that physical activity is one of the best antidotes to the challenges that often present themselves due to menopause. Why is a women's emotional and physical health compromised during menopause? Emotionally, one of the biggest challenges that women must face is the fact that they are no longer fertile. For some women this is a relief, but for others - particularly those who never had children, but wanted them - there may be a period of grieving. Even for women who have happily completed their families, menopause can be a sign associated with getting older, which many folks in our 'youth obsessed' culture may find difficult to accept. The hormone changes that occur during menopause can also contribute largely to mood swings or feelings of depression and anxiety. Physically, menopause can be difficult not only because of the hot flashes and other short-term symptoms it causes, but because the loss of estrogen can put women at risk for a diverse range of health problem. How can exercise influence menopausal symptoms? Research suggests that being physically active can reduce the frequency and severity of symptoms such as hot flashes, night sweats and sleep disturbances. Research also reveals that exercise has a positive effect on mood and can be useful for the depression that often coincides with "the change of life." Exercising in the morning may improve your sleep at night and exercise can certainly be one of the best defenses against the weight gain many women experience as they get older. The many benefits of regular exercise may include boosting your mood, strengthening your heart, improving your sleep and even promoting bone density. How can your fat-to-muscle ratio and BMI affect how you feel during perimenopause and menopause?  As we age our fat-to-muscle ratio increases and we tend to lose muscle mass and add fat - particularly around the abdomen. This so-called visceral fat, which turns our bodies from a pair to an apple shape, has been linked to an increased risk of type II diabetes, heart disease, gallbladder problems and even breast cancer. Carrying around extra fat and less muscle may or may not directly affect body mass index (BMI), but it will likely affect your risk of certain health problems, and it can also impact the way you feel. You may be more sluggish and have difficulty doing some of the things you did when you were leaner and in better shape (of course, some of that is to be expected due to normal aging). As fat shifts from your thighs and hips to your abdomen and upper body, you may notice your waistband and tops are feeling tighter, even if the scales aren't showing you have gained weight. What are your top tips for women who are beginning an exercise routine during menopause?  The main consideration is to play it safe. Exercise should be about making you healthy, not putting you at risk of an injury! This means you're going to need a little longer warm-up time than you did when you were younger. Allow about 10 minutes to warm up gradually - walking slowly, stretching, for example - before an exercise session. You should also avoid any exercises that may be unsafe - such as jarring exercises like jogging, jumping or high-impact aerobics if you have bone or joint problems. You can't get fit instantly - it is going to take time. I would also recommend that women make exercise enjoyable. Experiment with different types of exercise - dancing, walking, or working in the garden - until you find something you really like. Try taking classes where you can meet new people or arrange to walk with a friend. Mix up your exercise program to make it interesting - maybe dancing one day and yoga the next. I recently wrote a blog about new fitness gadgets and apps that will help you mix it up a bit. What are the best forms of exercise for women in their 40s, 50s, and 60s?  Staying physically active consistently is more important than engaging in any particular form of exercise; however, women in their 40s, 50s and 60s should make it a point to engage in three different forms of exercise: • Aerobic/ cardiovascular. This type of exercise, which includes walking, jogging, cycling, tennis, aerobics, working out on a elliptical machine - strengthens the heart and lungs and burns calories to help with weight loss or maintenance. • Strengthening. Exercises such as working out with dumbbells, resistance bands or exercise machines are helpful for strengthening muscles and bones and increasing metabolism to help with weight management. • Flexibility/stretching/range of motion. Stretching exercises, yoga and pilates can help keep our aging bodies more flexible and they can be particularly helpful for improving (or maintaining) joint function if joints are affected by arthritis. Beyond this, the particular exercises women do should be based on their likes and any health problems they might have. For example, women who have bad knees should avoid running or jogging, which would put extra stress on their knees. Women with osteoporosis (brittle bones) should avoid activities such as bicycling or sports that could put them at risk of impact that could break a bone. The best exercise is one you enjoy and will do regularly. How can women minimize the loss of muscle as they age?  Heed the old saying "use it or lose it." If you don't use your muscles you will lose muscle mass. For that reason, strengthening exercises are particularly important for women in their 40s and beyond. This includes working out with dumbbells, weight machines or resistance bands. For women who are just getting started with strengthening exercises or who have health concerns, I would recommend working with a physical therapist or personal trainer who can recommend a program specifically focused on your needs. Remember....whatever exercise program you decide to embrace, always check with your physician before you begin to make sure it is appropriate for your lifestyle. Follow Alexis Abramson, PhD: Facebook  Website  Twitter  LinkedIn info@abramson.com Disclaimer: Content and suggestions provided within should not be construed as a formal recommendation and AJA Associates, LLC makes no representations, endorsements or warranties relating to the accuracy, use or completeness of the information.

column2: Great Gifts for Older Adults in Your Life
column3:
It can be particularly difficult to find appropriate (and appreciated!) gifts for old people.  So what’s the secret to success when shopping for the senior in your life?  Do you go with practical or fun?  High-tech or low-tech?  Here are a few Dr. Alexis Approved great ideas that will hopefully help as you begin to tackle your gift list for the seniors in your life.

  The RuffGrip® Dog Leash – This leash makes walking a dog easier for people with gripping or dexterity problems due to arthritis in the joints of their hands.  The extra padding and no-slip grip is lightweight and provides extra control, while the super soft leather lining makes the leash extremely comfortable to hold.   Chef'n® PalmPeeler – For those folks in your life who have hands that are aching or shaky, this peeler is amazing.  Just slip your finger through the soft rubber ring on top for a natural feel and extremely easy peeling.  The users hand force is also minimized due to the unique design.   VTech CareLine  ™ - Want the senior in your life to stay socially connected?  Seniors are empowered to maintain active lifestyles and close relationships with this home telephone and personal communication system.  This product was designed to answer seniors’ daily communications needs and support hearing, dexterity or vision challenges. Features include large displays, photo speed dial, reminder capabilities, volume boost and a wearable pendant with one-button dialing that directly calls those pre-selected people who seniors communicate with most or for emergencies. Easy Grip Slant Tip Tweezers – These tweezers are specifically designed for those with gripping and dexterity challenges.  They are ready to use, right out of the easy to open package.  The rounded back rests in the palm of the hand for stability and control. The comfortable, soft rubber finger and thumb grips make the tweezers easy to hang on to while they are being used.  They also have precision tips with a unique gripping surface to tweeze fine and tiny hair.   Tee Pal Pro - Having a bad back doesn't mean that your aging loved one needs to give up golf.  In fact, the low-impact nature of the sport makes it an ideal physical activity for mature adults.  However, there are still challenges, including bending over to tee up the ball.  The Tee Pal Pro is a unique, lightweight, and ergonomic golf ball-teeing device, allowing users to remain upright so they don’t have to bend over to “tee up the ball”.      EasyWear Jacket and Pocket Cape – This versatile, practical, and super soft, Janska's EasyWear Jacket and Pocket Cape is a wardrobe staple. The minimalist design and thoughtful details, such as oversized buttons and generous armholes, can make getting dressed easier for people with gripping, dexterity, bending or reaching challenges. This unique clothing line was actually created by a caregiver who was frustrated with the scarcity of functional, stylish clothing options available to those with limited mobility.   Easi-Grip Cheese Slicer - The contoured handles of this product were re-molded in a soft feel plastic, which gives a firm comfortable grip in either hand. The stainless steel tools are set at 90 degrees from the handle, keeping the hand and wrist in a neutral stress free position.  Easi-Grip Knives and Kitchen Tools are super comfortable for everyone to use, but will be particularly beneficial for those with gripping and dexterity issues.   The Radius Trowel – This lightweight senior-friendly gardening tool features an innovative curved handle (called the Natural Radius Grip), making it user-friendly and comfortable even for people with arthritis of the joints in the hands. Intuitive and easy-to-use, this grip helps enable digging, even in tough soil, without putting excess strain on the hands or wrist.   Bathtub Steps – These steps add a great deal of safety and stability when getting in and out of the bathtub. The product provides a four-inch boost, with a slip-resistant textured top and rubberized feet enabling users to confidently climb over the tub wall, even in wet conditions.               Kettle/Teapot Tipper - Enjoy that nice cup of tea without the worry or concern of scalding yourself.  If you have gripping or dexterity challenges this product is perfect for you!  This ‘tipper’ allows the user to pour hot liquids safely and steadily without lifting any weight.  It is suitable for most types of teapots or electric kettles and comes with a Velcro strap for added security.  Made completely from plastic it is lightweight and corrosion resistant.  This product has a raised tilting platform that is designed to assist with pouring from any standard kettle with virtually no effort or risk of spilling boiling water.                  Garden Kneeler – This is the essential tool for any ‘green fingered’ person!  This product helps with the repetitive motion of getting up and down - which can be a strain on both the back and the knees. Made from robust steel with a soft comfortable kneeling platform, it also has arms that are just the right height to assist getting back up with stability in mind.  It weighs just 8 pounds so it’s not difficult to carry, it folds flat in seconds and can be easily stored away.   Two Handle Coffee Mug – This mug features extra large handles that allow for multiple gripping and lifting options for those with decreased dexterity. The two handle ceramic mug has a curved rim that helps prevent drips, and can be used with hot or cold beverages. The mug was designed to provide drinking independence for those with limited strength or other challenges that might prevent them from holding a traditional mug.                Swivel Seat - Turn any seat into a swivel seat cushion.  If you suffer from arthritis, leg, hip or back problems and have difficulty entering or exiting a car this swivel car seat is perfect for you.  The padded seat swivels 360° to offer you maximum comfort and turning mobility.  You can also use it on the seats in your kitchen, living room, or office.  Just position the swivel seat in place and it will swivel you easily in and out without pinching you or your clothes.   Disclaimer: Content and suggestions provided within should not be construed as a formal recommendation and AJA Associates, LLC makes no representations, endorsements or warranties relating to the accuracy, use or completeness of the information

column2: Great Exercise Programs for the 50+
column3: Well it's that time of year and New Years resolutions are in full motion today!  As usual one of the resolutions high on the list is how to get fit and healthy.  I've received SO many "health related" questions over the last week that I thought I would post one about a couple of new "boomer/senior specific" exercise programs that have been introduced to the market.  Below is a Dr. Alexis readers question and my response.  If any or you have tried either of these exercise programs and have any suggestions/ideas that will help our reader make a thoughtful choice please submit them to info@abramson.com or leave a note in the comments section below!  Many thanks in advance...YOU are always our best resource! Hi Dr. Alexis, I'm writing to ask your opinion about two classes that are offered at my local gym.  Since I recently got a basic membership level (so I could use the indoor track to walk FitBit mileage in the cold winter), I received their brochure about exercise classes.  Here are the two that caught my attention: T-Tapp and MeltMethod.  Do you know anything about these methods - and do you have an opinion?  Thanks! A.  Hello and Happy New Year!!!  Let me first say I've not personally tried either of these programs - I've heard of them both and can provide some insight I gleaned from reaching out to a couple of my colleagues who work specifically in the 60+ health and fitness arena.  That being said, here are my thoughts regarding the two exercise programs you asked me to review. T-Tapp:  I like this program because Teresa Tapp has created both a "general" class and one that is more well suited for the "mature" population.  Personally I feel this is important - there is no doubt that one can attend a general exercise class but our bodies and range of motion do change as we age (it's inevitable!) so it makes sense to be kind to ourselves and exercise at a level that will enhance our health - yet maintain a safe level of exertion.  The senior fit program also focus on areas that are critical as we age - maximizing muscle activation, circulation and lymphatic health, etc. (she calls it a Brain-Body Fitness Workout!)….Every exercise was apparently designed to improve strength, flexibility and heart health, as well as increase energy and decrease inflammation.  They say that "its special sequence of mindful movements combined with leverage isometrics will help your body rebuild from the inside out, improve posture and build better balance" - all very important areas to focus on as we age.  My colleagues say that the folks they works with really like this program and appreciate the changes that were incorporated to make it a "SAFE" workout at any age! MeltMethod:  This exercise regime seems to be extremely focused on reducing aches and pains associated with chronic conditions and stress (i.e. inflammation!).  I don't know your current level of fitness or your health status - but if stress and pain are problems you face this may be a great addition to your workout routine.  The website indicates that "MELT brings your body back to a more ideal state by directly enhancing body awareness, rehydrating connective tissue, and decreasing stuck stress that accumulates from daily living" - sounds good to me!  One person who tried the program said "the first time you MELT, you can see and feel a difference – and over time, you can transform how your body looks and feels" - also sounds good to me!  The exercise experts I talked to said it certainly can't hurt to incorporate MELT into your workouts because it is a proactive approach to getting a jump start on reducing the inflammation that is caused by the wear and tear we've all put on our bodies over decades of living life to its fullest! I'm not sure this suggestion makes sense for your busy schedule but I would truly recommend that you try to incorporate both programs into your workout routine.  It seems to me that since MELT supposedly only takes 10 minutes to complete perhaps it could be done in addition to T-Tapp or you could do each program on alternate days.  Otherwise, I would suggest you take one program on this time and the other the next time and decide what YOU think - we are all at such different fitness levels and dealing with our individual "aches and pains" (some days more than others) so at some level it becomes a very personal choice. Hope this helps at least a little bit!  I would be very interested in hearing which program you choose and your feedback. Cheers to your health, happiness, wealth and wisdom!  Dr. Alexis   Disclaimer: Content and suggestions provided within should not be construed as a formal recommendation and AJA Associates, LLC makes no representations, endorsements or warranties relating to the accuracy, use or completeness of the information

column2: Caffeine Sharpens Your Memory???
column3: I just read some interesting new research in the latest edition of THE WEEK....I thought I would share it with all of you....It was a fairly small study but it might make that morning "cup of joe" taste even better!!!! Coffee is one of the most popular beverages in the world for lots of reasons, including that it gives people a pleasant lift in the morning. New research shows that it also helps their memory. Researchers had 160 people who were not regular coffee drinkers look at pictures of objects; five minutes later they gave them either a placebo or a tablet containing 200 milligrams of caffeine—about the amount contained in a strong cup of coffee. The next day, participants were shown a broader set of images and asked to identify which ones were new, old, or similar. The caffeinated group was more likely to recognize slight differences in the pictures, such as a yellow rubber duck that was fatter than the one they’d seen the day before. “Without these tricky similar items, we would have found no effect of caffeine,” University of California, Irvine, neuroscientist Michael Yassa tells Forbes.com. “However, using these items requires the brain to make a more difficult discrimination—what we call pattern separation, which seems to be the process that is enhanced by caffeine.” It’s that form of memory that people use, for example, to recall where they last parked the car. Caffeine’s effect depends on the dosage, however: Researchers found that 100-milligram tablets didn’t improve memory, while 300-milligram doses caused headaches and jitteriness.

column2: Products to Help You Stay Independent
Caring for Someone with Alzheimer’s
column3:
The latest statistics reveal that one in three people will die with some form of Alzheimer’s disease or some other form of dementia, and Alzheimer’s disease recently escalated to become the sixth leading cause of death in the United States. It is estimated that five million people presently live with the disease, causing an estimated 210 billion dollars in health care costs each year.  One person is diagnosed every 76 seconds!!!  I can't think of more compelling data to support the fact that this is clearly a crisis that needs more attention and funding moving forward. Approximately 15 million individuals are caring for a person with Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) or another type of dementia in the U.S. Although memory loss is the most common symptom, others include confusion, lack of orientation and changes in personality and behavior. Individuals with AD require escalating levels of care, management and provisions for their safety. Because the disease slowly gets worse, caregivers often spend a very long time in the caregiving role. A recent survey found that 25% of those caring for someone with Alzheimer’s provide on average 40 hours of care weekly with about 75% performing physically demanding personal care including bathing, feeding and bathroom assistance.  Understandably, 40% of these caregivers reported high levels of emotional stress, particularly those who were working full or part-time; last year two-thirds of working caregivers missed work because of caregiving responsibilities and 8% turned down promotions.  It has been estimated that unpaid Alzheimer’s Disease caregivers provide an economic asset to our society worth almost $83 billion. To support these caregivers, the Alzheimer’s Research Foundation offers caregivers assistance through education, services, research and advocacy programs; such programs are at local, state and national levels. There is also funding available to assist family caregivers under the National Family Caregiver Support Program (NFCSP).  The Alzheimer's Foundation of America offers the following tips for success as you give the best care possible for a loved one with Alzheimer’s.

Alzheimer’s Caregiving Strategies for Success

  • Educate yourself about the disease. Read books, attend workshops and consult with healthcare professionals.
  • Learn caregiving techniques. Key areas are communication skills, safety concerns, managing behavioral challenges and activities of daily living.
  • Understand the experience of your loved one. Adjust your expectations. Be patient and kind.
  • Avoid caregiver burnout. Make time for yourself. Join caregiver support groups. Pursue interests beyond your caregiving role, such as exercise, hobbies, journaling and art.
  • Maintain your own physical and mental health. Exercise, respite and other activities can reduce stress. Seek medical help if there are signs of depression.
  • Discuss the situation with family and friends. Support systems are critical, especially when those you are caring for have a chronic condition which could potentially be long term.
  • Participate in cognitively stimulating activities with your loved one. Listening to music, doing word puzzles and partaking in memory games can easily be done at home.
  • Foster communication with physicians. Be involved in your loved one's medical care. Ask questions about the progression of the disease, express concerns and discuss treatment options.
  • Take care of financial, legal and long-term care planning issues. Try to involve your loved one in decision-making, if they are still capable of providing input, and consider their wishes related to future care and end-of-life issues.
  • Smile. Kindness, humor and creativity are essential parts of caregiving. Hugs, hand massages and other gentle physical contact will help your loved one feel connected and loved.
  • Think positively. Focus on your loved one's remaining strengths and enjoy your relationship while you are still able to.
Resources:
  • National Family Caregiver Support Program

  • www.aoa.gov

  • (877) 427-0220
  • www.alzheimers-research.org

column2: World Hypertension (High Blood Pressure) Day
column3:
World Hypertension Day, celebrated annually on May 17th, serves as a formal occasion to emphasize opportunities to improve prevention and control of hypertension – also known a high blood pressure. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention hypertension is a serious health issue affecting 67 million Americans, that’s one in every three adults and millions more teens and children. High blood pressure is a common problem in which the force of the blood against your artery walls is high enough that it may eventually put you at risk for life threatening health conditions. High blood pressure is a major risk factor for heart disease and stroke, the first and fourth leading causes of death for all Americans.  As highlighted in the recent global burden of disease study increased blood pressure is the leading risk for death and disability around the world.
Hypertension is a  "silent disease," often without warning signs or symptoms.  Fortunately, there’s more than medication that can help lower your blood pressure - making the proper lifestyle choices can help control blood pressure as well.  Incorporate these 5 tips into your daily routine to help properly control and monitor your blood pressure.

5 Tips to Control Hypertension

  1. Exercise on a Regular Basis– In order to stay healthy it’s important to get active and maintain a healthy weight. Regular physical activity has been shown to reduce blood pressure and may bring you back to a safe level.  People who are physically active have a lower risk of getting high blood pressure -- 20% to 50% lower -- than people who are not active. You don't have to be a triathlete to benefit from physical activity. According to the American Heart Association even light activities, if done on a regular basis, can help lower your risk.  The general rule is that it’s best to aim for 150 minutes of moderate physical activity per week.
  2. Stick to a Healthy Diet – According to webmd.com being overweight can make you two to six times more likely to develop high blood pressure than if you are at your desirable weight. Even small amounts of weight loss can make a big difference in helping to prevent and treat high blood pressure.  While it’s okay to indulge occasionally, keep your diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains and low-fat dairy products. Avoiding saturated fat and cholesterol, and reducing sodium can help reduce blood pressure.  Follow the Dietary Approach to Stop Hypertension (DASH), a flexible and balanced eating plan, for a healthy diet and stable blood pressure.
  3. Incorporate Home Monitoring – Don’t wait until your next doctor’s appointment; take readings at home with a remote blood pressure monitoring system such as the IDEAL LIFE BP Manager™.  This product allows you to take a reading in the comfort of your home and transmit it directly to your physician.  By monitoring your blood pressure regularly high blood pressure is more likely to be detected before drastic health risks occur.  This reliable blood pressure monitor is an easy-to-use device that quickly and accurately measures upper arm blood pressure and heart rate, and automatically and wirelessly communicates that data to your healthcare team.
  4. Reduce Your Stress – Stress has been routinely linked to potential increases in blood pressure. The American Heart Association maintains that we can all fight stress by incorporating healthy habits  into our busy lives.  When you’re feeling overwhelmed or anxious, consider meditating, getting a massage or practice a mindful low impact exercise like yoga.  Stress can make blood pressure go up, and over time may contribute to the cause of hypertension.  In today's fast-paced world filled with increasing demands, it's very important to manage your stress level in an effort to control your blood pressure.
  5. Watch What You Drink – The Mayo Clinic reports that if not consumed in moderation both caffeine and alcohol can raise your blood pressure by several points. To help prevent high blood pressure, and for overall health, the "Dietary Guidelines for Americans" recommends that you limit the amount of alcohol you drink to no more than two drinks a day for men and no more than one drink a day for women.  The Mayo Clinic suggests that if you have high blood pressure you should ask your doctor whether you should limit or stop drinking caffeinated beverages. If you're concerned about caffeine's effect on your blood pressure, try limiting the amount of caffeine you drink to no more than two 12-ounce cups of brewed coffee.
According to webmd.com less than half of those suffering from high blood pressure, 47 percent, have their condition under control.  Additional research indicates that when your blood pressure is high, you are 4 times more likely to die from a stroke, and you are 3 times more likely to die from heart disease.  By being proactive and monitoring your blood pressure on a regular basis, potential hypertension can hopefully be caught before more severe health conditions develop.     Disclaimer: Content and suggestions provided within should not be construed as a formal recommendation.  Neither AJA Associates, LLC or Alexis Abramson, PhD make any representations, endorsements or warranties relating to the accuracy, use or completeness of the information.
