column2: Stretch for Success
column3: Have you ever noticed how often dogs and cats stretch over the course of a day - especially after sleeping? We can all take a lesson from our four-footed friends, since regular stretching is as common as breathing is for them. It sends signals to the brain and body to get the blood flowing. If you’ve ever encountered a person who was so stiff they could barely walk, there’s a good chance they don’t stretch. Sometimes, it’s the simplest things that can make the biggest difference in your comfort level. In the morning, it can ease muscle stiffness by waking up your body with a series of simple arm, shoulder and chest extensions before starting your day. Stretching increases the range of motion in your joints as well as blood flow to muscle areas. Some of the biggest workout mistakes include forgetting to stretch and warm up prior to and after exercising. The practice actually lengthens muscles to increase muscle flexibility and is a must during physical therapy and rehabilitation. It protects the joints by warming the body up and decreasing the risk of exercise-related injury. It’s just as important to stretch your muscles back to their resting length after each workout. Exercising your muscles with resistance results in stronger - and temporarily shorter muscles. Shortened muscle fibers are more easily injured, so make sure to stretch properly after exercising when your muscles are still warm to minimize the soreness of post-workout muscles caused by microscopic muscle tears. A warm bath or shower will also suffice to warm you up, if you prefer. Stretching should never cause pain. Discover the pain threshold and kick it down a few notches before holding the stretch. Adjust your breathing rhythms to sync up with each movement to maximize their benefits, and never hold your breath when stretching. Check your range of motion on both sides of your body to ensure they are equal. Proper hydration will maximize the benefits of stretching. By the way, do you know how much water should you drink? Experts suggest at least eight- 8 ounce servings of water every day, or about .236 milliliters. That estimate is based on an average weight of 150 pounds and average body temperatures within your environment. Others suggest that there is no set requirement of water per day. You should always reach for water first when you are thirsty, as any added ingredients will dilute the hydration benefits of pure H2O. Verify that your urine is either white or slightly yellow as an indication that you are properly hydrated. Extremely dark urine can indicate dehydration or other possible health issues. Every individual has different water consumption requirements and it is difficult to apply a general rule. To stay hydrated, include at least 8 ounces of water with your stretching routine, and make sure you get your daily quota. There are certain conditions which are not conducive to stretching, including fractured bones and muscle and joint strains, as extending weakened muscles can result in further injury or impair the healing process. Check with your doctor first if you are experiencing any of these symptoms. If the back of your shoulder is tight, you may be prone to rotator cuff problems, common with golf, tennis and racquetball. Elongating the muscles in your upper back can promote good posture and ease problems associated with these types of activities. The Mayo Clinic offers an easy-to-follow stretching exercise slide show to guide you through the ten basic stretches that should be a regular part of your exercise routine. Try doing towel stretches or using a belt to isolate stretching exercises for your hamstrings, back muscles, shoulders and your quadriceps muscle groups. Quadriceps maintain alignment of the kneecap and the front of your shin. Regular stretching of this muscle group will relieve tightness and help avoid kneecap dislocations. The benefits of stretching are even greater for seniors, since it can actually reduce the wear-and-tear on aging and settling joints that experience friction. It also activates fluids in your joints, lengthens the individual muscle fibers, helps to remove waste products, and reduces muscle soreness. Flexibility is essential to maintain good health; without flexibility, a cycle of pain, stiffness and muscle loss will remain and invite unwanted toxins to settle into inactive joints and muscles. The simple habit of regular stretching will maintain the flexibility your body needs to ensure good overall health and increase longevity, and it’s something you can begin to do immediatel
column17: benefits|benefits of stretching|body|breathing|common|exercising|flexibility|health|joints|maintain|muscle|muscle fibers|muscles|pain|range of motion|regular stretching|stretch|stretching|warm|water

column2: How's Your quality of life
column3: No one envisions their final days confined to a wheelchair while eating applesauce and oatmeal for dinner. We all hope to achieve a good quality of life to sustain us until our last breath, but must also accept that certain factors are out of our control. Your lifelong habits contribute greatly to your overall well-being throughout the aging process. And it’s never too late to change bad habits that affect the quality of your life, such as over-eating or smoking. Evaluate problem areas to help unlock the why and how you react predictably to certain factors in life and to provide answers that can initiate change. Since 1937, a study has tracked 237 students at Harvard University and 332 socially disadvantaged youths from inner-city Boston through health, disease, and death in the quest to discover what keeps us happy and well. "The study shows that successful aging is not an oxymoron," says George Vaillant, professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School and director of the study for the past 35 years. "You can add life to your years instead of just years to your life.” Throughout the long-term study, Vaillant and his colleagues at Harvard University Health Services focused on seven predictors which are under our personal control, and if managed properly by the age 50, can lead to good physical and mental health through our 80’s and beyond. Obvious determining factors require us to quit smoking, exercise regularly, and not abuse alcohol. Some not-so-obvious indicators linked secondary education to overall good health and happiness, with money and social prestige trailing behind. "Despite great differences in parental social class, college-tested intelligence, current income and job status, the health decline of college-educated, inner-city men was no more rapid than that of Harvard College graduates," Vaillant points out. Other predicators in the study included marriage stability, exercise, weight management, and coping mechanisms. According to the study, uncontrollable factors that affect aging include family cohesion, genetic traits, and childhood temperament. What I find interesting about this long-term study is two of the factors that were classified as uncontrollable. The first is ‘family cohesion’. What if you could affect a positive change toward your own family’s ability and willingness to communicate more often, which also includes their emotional, and other types of support? Consider the variables that have affected your family’s cohesion, such as the relocation of close relatives to another city or state, and make it your mission to re-establish open lines of communication. It may require organizing a long-overdue family reunion or establishing and promoting a family-centered social media site with a format to encourage instant chats, photos sharing and plans for future family gatherings. The point is - you can make a positive difference in your family’s cohesion, and in the process, improve the quality of life for yourself and other family members. The second uncontrollable factor that is mentioned is ‘genetic traits’. Of course, your DNA is your genetic roadmap that is already set in motion from the moment of birth. What if you could learn enough through the study of your own DNA to increase your life by identifying a hereditary marker for certain diseases, such as hypertension or heart disease? At the time the Harvard study began in 1937, discussions about DNA and genetics were not on the table. But times have changed and on-going research findings from The Human Genome Project have been ground-breaking in proving mankind now has the ability to identify genetic markers and in doing so may be able to keep you from falling into previously hidden pitfalls that are a part of your genetic path. Scientists are perfecting the science of epigenetics, which is proving that each gene has a layer that functions like ‘on’ and ‘off’ switches and we now know it is possible to change the expression of our genes – and particularly those that are indicators of diseases and malfunctions in our bodies. Although these types of tests haven’t become mainstream yet, you should expect to see more of this research affecting the quality of your preventative healthcare in the not-to-distant future to improve your genetic disposition toward a specific disease before it becomes a factor in your health, setting you on a preventative maintenance course that adds years to your time clock. To make sure quality goes hand-in-hand with the quantity of your golden years, keep things interesting by changing up your routine from time to time. If you find your weeks running together like an automatic wash, rinse and repeat cycle, it’s time to switch to the manual cycle and change the itinerary. A chronically sedentary life symbolizes resting on your laurels, and can be the fast track to early death. Include physical activity in your daily life to enhance blood flow to the brain and crank up your fun factor. Even if you are restricted by limited mobility, there are some activities and destinations that are well-equipped to handle accessibility issues, so you can still enjoy a quality life. Don’t allow immobility or other physical restrictions to become a crutch that hinders your options for enjoyment. Gravitate toward places that accept and solve these challenges to help overcome the stigma of physical limitations. Family-oriented venues, such as Disney theme parks offer services for patrons with disabilities that can range from blindness, hearing, cognitive and mobility impairment. As mainstream America recognizes the value of welcoming the mass numbers of our aging population along with their families into the recreational mix, theme parks and family-oriented destinations cater to mobility-challenged patrons by providing streamlined access to attractions and rides, which also extends the perk of shorter waiting lines to accompanying family members. Share your family’s enthusiasm for excitement by joining in the adventure. It doesn’t matter if the family vacation is a Caribbean cruise or a trip to the Smithsonian Museum, there’s really no reason not to participate. In the big picture, it’s the quality of our days that defines our life. Resignation has no place in a happy heart. Instead, adopt a can-do attitude as you complete everyday tasks. Reach for the next milestone to keep clear sight of a high-quality life with long-term goals.
column17: aging|change|cohesion|family|family cohesion|family members|family's|family's cohesion|genetic|genetic traits|harvard|harvard university|health|life|long-term study|physical|quality|quality of life|study|time

column2: Genetics and you
column3: Genetics leave a breadcrumb trail for your descendants to follow. Your achievements are not only a reflection of your life, but incentive for others to duplicate the pattern, particularly when it comes to achieving a high-quality long life. Genetics is a factor when it comes to understanding our physical and biological strengths and weaknesses. Certain diseases are inherited, such as heart disease, but the shift toward healthy diets and exercise creates a new playing field that is coached by medical breakthroughs and surgical procedures to combat pre-existing and genetically inherited diseases, giving us all reason to hope for centenarian status. While understanding DNA is not at the top of everyone’s list, it’s helpful to know it is often referred to as the ‘molecule of heredity.’ The Human Genome Project was organized in the late 1980s and is a vast undertaking created solely for the purpose of exploring the genetic roadmap of human DNA. A book entitled, “Drawing the Map of Life: Inside the Human Genome Project,” explains that during the race to pin down the human sequence, the focus has shifted from discovering how alike we are to how different we are from each other. The ability to find disease markers in human DNA is creating a major shift toward preventive medicine, with the ability to increase the quality of life across the board. Efforts to expand this knowledge base have resulted in the recent and ongoing harvest and testing of tens of thousands of human DNA samples. By prioritizing, scientists can now begin to identify the DNA markers that make certain individuals more prone to certain diseases in a quest to discover which drugs benefit particular patients. The project has been active since the Clinton administration, and continues to make strides in understanding DNA, the building blocks of life. “But while genes are certainly an important component of aging, they may not be the most relevant factor,” writes Alice Park in a cover story for Time Magazine, entitled “How to Live 100 Years.” “The good news is that according to animal studies, only about 30% of aging is genetically based, which means that the majority of other variables are in our hands. Not only can getting such factors under control help slow the aging process before it starts, it can also help those who are already in their golden years improve their fitness and strength.” The article also shares findings of recent studies showing that when seniors from ages 65 to 75 exercise with resistance weights, they can improve their scores on cognitive tests of memory and decision-making. Research proves that when people over 65 participate in regular physical activity, they lower the chance of developing cognitive impairment. Dr. Bruce Yankner, a researcher at Harvard Medical School, is studying what distinguishes brains that make it to 100 years with limited cognitive decline from those that succumb to the ravages of Alzheimer's disease or other forms of dementia before age 85. This is a huge area of concern, since upward of 16 million people will develop Alzheimer’s disease by the year 2020, if a cure isn’t found. Yankner zeroed in on genes in the frontal cortex - which are involved in higher learning, planning and goal setting - of people ages 24 to 106. That's a big chronological span, and it netted a big genetic haul: the research confirmed our genes start to slow down after age 40. Using that information as a starting point, Yankner's group is trying to determine just what those genes do to affect individual aging processes. Now more than ever, the medical community is focused on pinpointing links and cures to the genetic disposition of Alzheimer’s disease, since it is on the horizon for over 16 million people at the rate of one new diagnoses every 76 seconds. Yankner points to extenuating circumstances that are also a player in the picture. He states, “DNA is not destiny. Just as you can keep your body fit with good lifestyle habits and by avoiding pollutants, toxins and carcinogens, you may be able to keep your genes healthier. Environmentally triggered alterations in genes - known as epigenetic changes - can affect when a gene is activated, how robustly it is turned on and how it interacts with neighboring genes. Free radicals provide a very good case study of how epigenetic processes play out.” Epigenetic inheritance may not be as easy to detect as DNA traits are, and it can manifest more quickly in response to signals from the environment and direct experiences of parents, which adds another dimension to the modern picture of evolution.
column17: aging|alzheimer's disease|certain diseases|cognitive|disease|diseases|dna|genes|genetic|genome project|human|human dna|human genome|human genome project|life|medical|people|project|understanding|understanding dna

column2: Is there a fountain of youth?
column3: Did you know that scientists say we have two ages? No, I am not talking about the one your driver’s license says you are (the one some of us like to pretend we are) – I'm talking about your chronological and biological ages. Your chronological age is the number of years you have been alive while your biological age refers to how old you seem to be. (Have you ever met someone and thought, “Wow I would never guessed she was 70!” or “Seriously, she’s only 45?”) On the outside the age you seem to be could be influenced by the number of gray hairs or your head or lines on your face, the way you carry yourself or the way your body carries weight, your attitude toward new ideas or your willingness to embark on new adventures. On the inside, an important indication of your age – how old you seem to be – is the length of your telomeres. Telomeres are the protective caps at the end of our chromosomes (imagine the plastic or metal coating on the ends of your shoelaces) that help them remain stable. As cells divide, the telomeres become shorter. As they become shorter, their structural integrity weakens (imagine frayed laces once that protective end is broken) and the cells age and die quicker. During the past decade or so research has linked shorter telomeres with a number of diseases related to aging, including cardiovascular disease, diabetes, osteoporosis, and stroke. Obviously, your biological age is very important. Chronological age? Not so much so. Sure, it was a big deal when you were younger. After all, it determined when you could get your driver’s license, buy alcohol, or vote. (It didn’t really matter how old you seemed to be when it came to those things.) But now – for the most part, at least – your chronological age is just a number. So if you’re caught in a rut of thinking a “50-year-old shouldn’t do that,” a “60-year-old could never do that” or “70 is way too late to start doing that,” get out of it now. While you certainly can’t change your chronological age you can change your biological age. Research out of UC San Francisco suggests that through changes in lifestyle – exercising, eating healthfully, managing stress and having good social supports – you may actually lengthen telomeres – and your life. (See Chapter 2: “Counteracting Bad Habits” for more healthy lifestyle changes.) You can also change the age you seem to be, making yourself look, feel and act younger. In other words, youth and longevity is not a matter of sheer luck. If you don’t believe me, check out my top 13 picks for looking and feeling younger.
column17: 70|age|ages|biological|biological age|cells|change|changes|chronological|chronological age|driver's|driver's license|end|imagine|license|number|protective|research|talking|telomeres

column2: Drink Up! Water That Is.....
column3:
No road down Florida’s east coast is complete without a stop in historic St. Augustine and Ponce de Leon's Fountain of Youth Archaeological Park. Located in the area first explored by Juan Ponce de Leon in 1513, the park features the remains of the first successful European settlement in the New World -- including what Ponce de Leon believed to be the elusive Fountain of Youth. When my family made that trip when I was young, my parents thought it would be educational for my brother and me to see the Spanish Lookout Tower and archaeological excavations in the oldest U.S. city. I, however, was more interested seeing the Fountain of Youth. Although intellectually I knew, even at a young age, there was no such thing as eternal youth, in my imagination I saw old people – like 30 or something – splashing in the fountain and drinking to their hearts’ contents. Imagine my disappointment when I discovered the fountain was a spring accessed by a well and the only drink we could take from it was lukewarm and in a paper cup. What I didn’t realize at the time was how vital that spring’s water was to the survival of some our nation’s earliest settlers and how vital water is to our health and longevity today. Consider these facts about water:
  • The average woman’s body is about 55 percent water. By the time we feel thirsty we have already we have already lost about 2 to 3 percent of our body’s water.
  • While humans can live up to three weeks (pretty miserable weeks, of course) without food, we will likely die within three days without water.
  • One-fifth of our body’s water is in blood plasma. It flows through the blood, carrying oxygen and nutrients to cells. Water also cushions our joints, protects our brains and helps regulate our body temperature.
  • Drinking water regularly helps flush our bodies of toxins, aids in digestion and even keeps our skin younger and healthier looking.
So how much water do you need? Many experts suggest at least eight 8-ounce glasses of water daily (more in warm weather and if you are exercising). Others suggest there is no set requirement of water per day, but that you should always reach for water when you are thirsty, as any added ingredients will dilute the hydration benefits of pure H20. To ensure you are getting enough, take a look at your urine. If it is straw-colored or pale yellow, you are probably getting enough water. If it is a slightly darker yellow, you could stand to drink more. Darker urine – the color of amber or honey – means you are not getting enough water and need some right away. Very dark urine – the color of syrup or brown ale – could indicate severe dehydration or liver disease. Increase your water consumption and monitor your urine color. If it doesn’t lighten up, call your doctor. Your water doesn’t need to come from a fabled fountain or fancy bottle to benefit you. In fact, I advise against buying bottled water. In many cases it is merely taken from a municipal source, probably no different from what comes from you tap. (Read the label.) Regardless of the source of the water inside, most of the bottles --perhaps more than 85 percent -- wind up in landfills. So do yourself and the environment a favor by filling your favorite to-go cup with your own well-filtered tap water, and drink up! How to Ensure Healthy Tap Water Want to know what’s in the water that comes from your tap? Under the "right-to-know" provisions in the drinking water law, all tap water suppliers must provide annual water quality reports to their customers. To obtain a copy, contact your water provider. If you’re concerned about impurities, buy a filter to attach to your tap. Better yet, if you can afford one – they are a bit pricy – have a high-quality water filtration system installed at the entry point of your water source to benefit from the highest purity level possible for all of your bathing, cooking and drinking water requirements.
column17: archaeological|body's water|color|de|de leon|drink|drinking|drinking water|fountain|fountain of youth|getting enough water|ponce|ponce de|ponce de leon|source|tap|tap water|urine|urine the color|youth

column2: 9 Bad Habits You Need to Change Now
column3:
If you’ve taken a look in the mirror or glanced around the room at a recent class reunion it’s no secret how much our bodies change with age. Skin loses elasticity, leading to wrinkles and creases; fat storage shifts from the hips and thighs to the abdomen, causing our pear-or hour-glass-shaped bodies to more closely resemble a beach ball; and hair thins in some areas and crops up troublingly in others. And that’s just part of what’s visible on the outside. There are also changes going on inside that we cannot see: bones lose density, blood vessels (which, like our skin, are made up of collage) become less supple; organs, including our kidneys and livers, function less efficiently; and our senses become less, well sensitive. We may not see, hear, smell or taste as keenly as we did when we were younger. Lots of other things don’t work as well as when we were younger either. Taking care of our bodies takes on a whole new importance. Bad habits you may have gotten away with when you were younger – eating poorly, skimping on sleep, spending long hours at a desk – may start to catch up with you. The good news is that it is not too late to adopt new ones habits. Doing so may not only prevent further damage, but in some cases can help reverse the damage from less-than-wise choices. Here are 9 habits you need to change now – and why..... 1. Overeating If you were one of those teenagers or 20-somethings who could eat anything you wanted and still stay pencil thin (by the way, I never liked your type), you’ve probably discovered the endless smorgasbord comes at a price. Genetic factors, decreasing muscle mass, reduced activity levels and even lack of sleep (more about that shortly) can contribute to weight gain as you age – particularly after menopause. Excessive weight is more than a nuisance that affects your appearance and prevents you from fitting in that little black dress or snapping your pants. Fat that accumulates around your midsection in particular produces hormones and other substances that can profoundly influence your health and puts you at risk for   a host of problems including diabetes, heart disease and some cancers. Some women tell me they gain now just looking at food. While I certainly don’t think that is possible, looking at food can tempt you to take a bite, and sometimes taking just a bite – if you do it frequently enough – can start to pack on the pounds. Suppose your friend is eating a Big Mac. Watching her savor those two all beef patties, special sauce, lettuce and cheese – oh the cheese! – is more than your willpower can bear. She offers you a bite. At 560 calories for the entire burger, let’s say your bite has about 50 calories. No harm done. But what if she offered you a bite of her Big Mac (or something calorically comparable) every day for a year? By this time next year you would have consumed an extra 18,250 calories, which translates to a weight gain of more than five pounds – a big price to pay for just a bite! The good news from this example is that losing weight is possible through small acts as well. Let’s say you are eating enough to maintain a stable weight. If you pass up the equivalent of a Big Mac bite each day, you could lose more than five pounds by next year – just by passing on one bite! Right now I use the example of a Big Mac purely for its calorie content. We’ll get into the issue of nutrients good and bad shortly. But whether you are consuming too many calories from hamburgers and candy bars or from healthier more healthy choices like avocados and almond milk, the result is largely the same – weight gain. Therefore, overeating -- even if’s the good stuff -- is not good. So what causes us to overeat and, more importantly, how we can stop doing it is an area that has intrigued researchers, including Brian Wansink, professor and director of the famed Cornell University Food and Brand Lab and author of Mindless Eating: Why We Eat More Than We Think. Research by Wansink gives us this advice for limiting portion sizes. Understand portion sizes: Sometime we eat large portions because we don’t know what constitutes a portion. When trying to measure portions, a good rule of thumb is to use your thumb – or the palm of your hand, or a domino. A one-ounce serving of peanut butter is approximately the size of your thumb, a 3-ounce serving of meat is about the size of your palm, and a one-ounce serving of cheese is about the size of domino. Take it slow. If your rush though a plate of your favorite pasta dish, chances are you will want another. That’s because it takes a few minutes for your stomach to tell your brain that’s it full. By eating slowly, you will not only have more time to savor your favorite foods, but you will also reduce the desire to fill a second plate when one is enough. Choose your plates wisely. The size and even the color of the plates can make a difference in how much you eat. If you use a small plate and fill it to the edge your brain will think you are eating more than if you place the same amount of food in the center of a large plate. And though it sounds crazy, you’ll eat less food if it’s served on plate that’s different in color from the food you are eating. In other words, no mashed potatoes or macaroni on white plates. Wansink says the higher the contrast between and plate the more you realize just how large your serving is. Put it out of sight. Remember the Big Mac your friend was eating? Do you think you would have taken that bite if that burger if your friend had been eating it in another room – better yet, at her own house? Probably not. It was the sight of the Big Mac (probably along with the smell and your friend’s obvious enjoyment) that made you want it. In one study by Wansink women ate more candy from a clear dish than from an opaque dish that made the candy less visible to them. The take-home message: if you shouldn’t eat it, don’t have it where you can see it. Pick small packages. It’s easy to overeat when there’s a lot in front of you to eat. Whether it’s a piece of fruit or a bag of chips, people tend to think of a single unit as a serving, so smaller units mean smaller servings and less chance of overeating. If you’d prefer not to spend extra on single-serving sizes or 100-calorie packs of packaged foods, buy a larger package and divide it into individual servings. When you are ready to eat, take one serving only and put the rest out of sight. Avoid distractions. The more focused you are on something else – a TV show, a conversation at the next table – the less you are focused on what you are eating, which can cause you to eat more. One study even showed that women ate more when they sat at the table in a messy kitchen. So clean up the kitchen and focus on your food, and you’ll be more likely to eat less. 2. Eating junk food I once worked with a woman for whom break time always meant a trip to the break room vending machines. One day as we continued a discussion that had begun at our desks, I watched as she dropped quarters into the machine. “What are you getting?” I asked, just before a package of crackers fell past a glass window in the machine. “Lunch,” she smiled. “Now it’s time to choose dessert,” eyeing a fair-sized chocolate chip cookie sealed in cellophane.   I can’t say that my friend was overeating. In fact, her vending machine meal would have left a Chihuahua hungry. Nor was she consuming too many calories. With her package of crackers and cookie each weighing in at just under 200 calories – OK, I’m addicted to reading food labels, so I discretely looked! -- her meal had about half the calories of a turkey sandwich with Swiss at the deli next door. Yet what she was eating was just plain bad.   While eating like my friend did is not likely to lead to weight gain, it can lead to other problems by subjecting your body to ingredients it doesn’t need while depriving it of nutrients it does.   If you’re ready to give up a junk food habit, here are three ingredients you need to watch for as well as some tips to minimize or eliminate them.   Trans fats Many packaged foods, such as my friend’s vending machine lunch, contain trans fats. Trans fats may be natural or artificial. Natural trans fats are produced in the guts of some animals, and the meat and milk for these animals may contain them. Artificial trans fats, which are far more common, are produced through an industrial process that adds hydrogen to vegetable oils to make them solid. Food manufacturers use these trans fats (also referred to as partially hydrogenated oils) to increase the shelf life and improve the taste and texture of packaged foods. Many fast food restaurants use them to fry foods because they can be reused many times, making them an economical cooking method. But trans fats also have a serious downside. They raise your LDL (bad) cholesterol and lower your HDL (good) cholesterol. Trans fat consumption is linked with increased risk of heart disease, stroke and type 2 diabetes. In 2013, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) made a preliminary determination that partially hydrogenated oils are no longer Generally Recognized as Safe (GRAS) in human food.   Trans fats are present in many products, including many fried foods and baked goods. To determine if and how much trans fats a food contains check the Nutrition Facts panel, which lists trans fats, or check the ingredient list for partially hydrogenated oils.   To reduce or eliminate trans fat consumption, replace trans fats in your diet with healthy monounsaturated fats or polyunsaturated fats. Consume a diet that emphasizes whole foods, including fruits, vegetables, whole-grains, poultry, fish nuts and low-fat dairy products. Limit the amount of fried foods (like donuts and chicken nuggets) you eat as well as packaged baked goods like cookies, muffins and cakes. When cooking, use unhydrogenated vegetable oils such as safflower, sunflower, canola and olive oil.   Sugars Whether they go by the name high fructose corn syrup, sucrose or glucose, processed and refined sugars are everywhere. And while they tempt you with their sweetness they are not your friend.   The massive amounts of refined sugars contained in the typical Western diet are designed to stimulate appetites and increase consumption, and they do a pretty good job of it. Approximately one third of all calories in the average American diet come from refined sugar and corn syrup.   All of that sugar is associated with a lot of our most common health problems: obesity, kidney stones, tooth decay, diabetes, heart disease and diabetes, to name a few. Processed sugar also plays a role in the possible onset of insomnia, depression, hypertension, colon and pancreatic cancer, skin breakouts and metabolic syndrome. Refined sugar depletes the body of B vitamins and other nutrients, which can lead to indigestion and allergies. Research has even linked sugar to brain shrinkage and cognitive decline. If you’d like to reduce the sugar in your diet, a good place to start is with soft drinks, the single largest source of refined sugar in the American diet. The average American consumes 53 gallons of soft drinks every year. The average can of soda has about 40 grams, or 10 teaspoons of sugar. One large 64-ounce soda contains approximately 53 teaspoons of sugar!   The next time you are craving a cola, give one of the vast variety of herbal and natural teas a try. You may find that you can replace a soda craving with a flavor to suit every taste and mood, including fruit-infused varieties and others that ease stress. Consider adding a touch of lemon and natural honey or agave nectar instead of unhealthy sugar for sweetness or to soothe a dry or scratchy throat. If you need a pick-me-up only caffeine can give you, choose coffee over soda. Coffee, in moderation, is actually considered beneficial to trigger the brain and aid in memory tasks. One caveat: in the afternoon, stick with decaf or you may find yourself restless and jittery at bedtime.   For a sweet treat, look for naturally sweet foods like locally produced honey and ripe fruits such as dates and figs. Avoid long-term use of artificial sweeteners, as they too, have been linked with health problems. For a safe sugar alternative try stevia. Made from the stevia plant, it is void of calories or carbohydrates in its purest state. Stevia is available in several liquid and granule forms, under different brand names. If you’re looking for pure stevia, be sure to read the package, many products contain added ingredients to improve their shelf life.   Salt The U.S. Food and Drug Administration recommends limiting sodium consumption to 2,300 milligrams daily – or to no more than 1,500 mg daily if you have high blood pressure. If you regularly eat at fast food restaurants and/or prepare meals using processed and refined foods, there’s a good chance you’re consuming twice that limit -- as much as 3,500 to 5,000 milligrams daily. [Alexis, do you remember where you got this figure? It was in your book.]   Restaurants and snack food manufacturers add a lot of salt to foods because it is cheap way to make foods taste good and is habit forming. (Did you ever wonder why you couldn’t eat just one potato chip?) Bars serve salty snacks because they increase thirst and get you to buy more drinks. But you’ll also find salt in less- expected places than bowls on bar counters and potato chip bags. Leading sources of sodium include canned vegetables, prepackaged cereals and frozen meals, even the ones that claim to be healthy. If your taste buds are not as sensitive as they were when you were younger you may be tempted to shake on more salt – or you might not notice as much when foods are highly salty. But beware.   Excessive salt consumption is a contributor to increased risk for heart attack and stroke. Scientists from the Harvard Medical School and the Harvard School of Public Health now believe that eating too much salt contributed to 2.3 million deaths from heart attacks, strokes and other heart-related diseases throughout the world in 2010, representing 15 percent of all deaths due to these causes. With a growing body of evidence positioned against the use of salt, it only makes sense to limit it and look for healthier flavor-enhancing alternatives, such as paprika and saffron, to reduce salt cravings.   Ideally your diet should be low in all of these. But that doesn’t mean a healthy diet should always be about what you can’t eat. There are many delicious foods you should eat and nutrients you should add to your diet for health and longevity. One of the main reasons I hear from women for not eating healthfully is that they have little incentive to cook or prepare healthy meals, particularly if they live alone. Others say their busy lives leave little time for cooking. After a long day it’s far too tempting to make a trip through a drive-thru or pop frozen entrées into the microwave.   I recommend preparing your own frozen dinners. Pick one time a week – say Sunday afternoons – to prepare cook a few entrees. Better yet invite a friend or two to bring ingredients for a favorite meal to share and make it a party. Divide into individual freezable containers, label and place in the freezer for days when you don’t have the time or desire to cook. Just steam few vegetables to enjoy with your entrée and add fruit for dessert.   Homemade frozen dinners are also great to take to work. Bring along some carrot sticks or a celery stick and a piece of fresh fruit to minimize temptations from the vending machine. It’s never too late – or too soon – to start eating healthfully.  
  1. Being sedentary
  If a busy career and family life left little time for exercise, if you worked late into the evenings and had lunch at your desk, or if your interests leaned more toward sewing or keeping up with the soaps than gardening or playing tennis, your sedentary lifestyle could eventually catch up with you.   A lack of physical activity has been linked to a wide range of health problems, including obesity, osteoporosis, cognitive decline, depression, increased susceptibility to infections, and increased risk of diabetes heart attack, stroke, breast and colon cancer.   The good news: it’s not too late get active and start reaping the benefits of regular exercise. Not sure how much or what type of exercise you need? See Chapter 3: “Too Fit to Quit.”   The even better news is that you don’t have to do marathon exercise sessions to benefit. If you can’t walk or jog for 30 minutes at a time, three 10-minute walks or jobs will be just fine. In fact, if you haven’t been active in a while, it’s important to start slowly. It’s also a must to see your doctor before beginning a vigorous exercise program and be sure to check out Chapter 3: “Too Fit to Quit” to learn how regular exercise can benefit your body, mind and spirit and for guidelines on choosing the right exercise and amount of exercise for you.  
  1. Skimping on sleep
We’ve all had our share of late or sleepless nights cramming for exams, partying with friends, working to meet a deadline or nursing a child. While an occasional night of little or no sleep may be inevitable, routinely skimping on sleep is a habit to be avoided.   Unfortunately in our society, sleep deprivation is often viewed as a virtue (like passing up a slice of pie) or as a sign of dedication (burning the midnight oil to complete a project) or even genius (Thomas Jefferson reportedly slept only four to five hours nightly). In actuality, sleep time is more than a disruption to a busy day, and the need for sleep is not a sign of weakness. Adequate sleep is essential to our physical and mental health, productivity and safety.   Sometimes the dangers of sleep deprivation can be felt instantly (such as crashing your car because you have dozed off or your reaction times were slowed), but more often they are insidious, as long-term sleep loss contributes to problems such as heart disease, obesity and diabetes.   Why? According to the Heart Blood and Lung Institute it is during sleep that our bodies heal and repair of tissues including the heart and blood vessels. Sleep also maintains the balance of hormones that make you feel hungry (ghrelin) or full (leptin).   When you don't get enough sleep, your ghrelin level goes up and your leptin level goes down. As a result you feel hungrie than you would after a good night’s sleep. https://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health/health-topics/topics/sdd/why   Sleep also affects how your body reacts to insulin, the hormone that controls your blood glucose (sugar) level. When you don’t get enough sleep your blood sugar levels rise, which may increase your risk for diabetes.   Sleep is also important to the health of your immune system and its ability to defend you against infection. It’s no coincidence when you come down with a cold or flu after a period of sleep deficiency. And when you do, inadequate sleep can make it harder for your body to fight infections.   What exactly is adequate sleep? The answer differs to a degree depending on your age. According to the National Sleep Foundation, adults 26 to 64 need 7-9 hours of restful sleep each night to maintain good health and mental focus. For those 65 and older, the range goes down to 7-8 hours nightly, but still more than most people in that age group get. [Alexis, new figures from the National Sleep Foundation: https://sleepfoundation.org/how-sleep-works/how-much-sleep-do-we-really-need/page/0/2]   If you’re having a hard time getting the sleep you need, the Foundation offers these tips to boost your sleep mood and send you off to dreamland sooner.
  • Stick to a schedule. Practice going to bed and getting up at the same time every day, even on vacations and weekends. This helps regulate and program your body’s internal clock for sleep.
  • Avoid cigarettes and tobacco products. They are not good for you under any circumstances, but if you need another reason to avoid them, they disrupt sleep.
  • Eliminate afternoon and evening caffeine. The caffeine in coffee, tea, many soft drinks and even chocolate is a stimulant that can interfere with sleep. For an afternoon slump, reach for a healthy snack of yogurt or nuts. If you’re accustomed to an evening cup of coffee or tea, try caffeine-free versions. Having a cup of herbal tea, such as chamomile, before bedtime can help relieve stress and relax your muscles.
  • Keep your windows covered. Layer your bedroom windows with functioning treatments, such as traversing draperies and operable blinds that can block out light when a daytime sleep-in is called for, and provide extra insulation during weather extremes.
  • Silence the phone. Resist the urge to leave your cell phone bedside, unless it is part of your security plan, and consider muting the ringer to avoid unwanted wake-up calls.
  • Turn off the TV. While enjoying the entertainment value it offers in the privacy of your bedroom is appealing, try to avoid depending on the TV as a crutch to help you fall asleep. Instead, opt for listening to soft, instrumental music to relax your mind at bedtime.
  • Get exercise. A good workout in the day can promote sleep at night, but be careful complete workouts at least 3 hours before bedtime. Any later and they can leave you stimulated and unable to sleep.
  • Keep your room cool. Avoid turning up the thermostat at bedtime, as resting body temperatures require less heat and will relax better in a room that is dark, cool and comfortable. The ideal temperature: between 60 and 67 degrees.
  • Take an old fashioned approach. Although it may seem old fashioned, a glass of warm milk and a warm bath at bedtime can encourage slumber.
  • Avoid sleep aids. Avoid antihistamine-containing over-the-counter sleep aids except for occasional use, if your doctor recommends them. Although they may make you drowsy and induce sleep they do not address the cause of sleeplessness and they carry the risk of side effects including blurred vision, dizziness, dry mouth and constipation. A better choice: melatonin, a hormone made by your brain’s pineal gland that helps control sleep and wake cycles, and is available as a dietary supplement.
  If you’re getting the required number of sleep hours – or at least think you are – and still waking up feeling unrefreshed or feeling sleepy throughout the day, you may be suffering from sleep apnea, a condition in which your breathing stops repeatedly throughout the night, causing you to you to awaken. Be sure to mention it the next time you see your doctor. An evaluation may be in order and treatment is available.  
  1. Being careless with oral care
  Having a dirty mouth has nothing to do with using language that would make your mother ashamed. All of our mouths are full of bacteria and other ugly bugs, collecting on our teeth in a sticky film called plaque and waiting to wreak havoc. Unless you are diligent about brushing and flossing the bacterial will use sugars in the foods you eat to produce acids that will eat away at your tooth enamel causing cavities.   Plaque that is not removed eventually forms tartar, a harder-to-remove substance that can collect at the gum line and cause gingivitis -- gums that are red, swollen and prone to bleeding when you brush. Uncontrolled gingivitis can further progress to periodontitis, a condition where bacteria in the mouth invade the structures that support teeth, leading to the breakdown of gum tissue and underlying bone and eventually tooth loss.   If that’s not enough to have you rushing to find a flosser, the effects of periodontal disease are not confined to your ability to comfortably chew foods or smile; bacteria that enter the bloodstream through your gums can travel to other parts of the body, setting off an inflammatory response that could potentially cause of a wide range of problems from increasing your risk of cardiovascular disease to worsening inflammatory diseases like rheumatoid arthritis.   There is even some evidence that the bacteria cause periodontitis, including Streptococcusmutans, Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, Porphyromonas gingivalis, can be passed through intimate oral contact or the sharing of drinking cups and silverware. So for the sake of your smile, your health and that of your romantic partners, it is important to take good care of your mouth.   If you haven’t always been faithful about flossing, now is the time to start, using dental floss or tape once a day. If you find it difficult to floss prefer something a little more high tech, try an oral irrigator (you’re likely to know them by the name WaterPik). Oral irrigators have been shown to clean between the teeth and below the gum line. Research suggests that when combined with brushing, oral irrigators not only remove plaque but may also reduce inflammatory substances in the gum tissue.   Also consider the benefits of adding oil-pulling to your oral care routine. Oil pulling involves gently swishing about a tablespoon of coconut and sesame oil around in the mouth, usually for 10 to 20 minutes per day. The premise is that the fatty cell membranes of the bacteria in the mouth adhere to the oils. When you spit out the oil, the harmful bacteria go with it. Oil pulling is not only super trendy, but it has a long track record – it’s a type of Ayurvedic medicine that dates back 3,000 years.   If your dentist recommends it, use a fluoride rinse – either prescription or over-the-counter --to strengthen tooth enamel.   Speaking of your dentist, it may be time you started seeing more of him or her. Even if you have been faithful about twice yearly checkups and cleanings it may be wise to increase their frequency and perhaps intensity. If you have signs of periodontal disease, your dentist may recommend root scaling and planing, a procedure that involves scaling the plaque, bacteria and toxins from the tooth and root surfaces and then smoothing the rough areas on root surfaces. It’s a little more unpleasant than a typical cleaning, but for many people it helps improve the health of the roots and gum tissues so that no further specific treatment is necessary.   Even if your teeth and gums are in tip top shape regular oral checkups and cleaning can help keep them that way. They also allow your dentist to detect lesions or other changes in the mouth that could be early indicators of cardiovascular disease and stroke.   In short, don’t be careless with oral care -- there are probably more reasons that you ever realized to take care of your mouth.  
  1. Drinking too much
  For many of my friends in college, drinking was a primary source of entertainment. Although most of us have probably drunk more than we should have on at least a few occasions, excessive drinking is never good. Short term it can land you in a ditch, a jail cell, or worse. Long term, excessive use of alcohol can lead to serious health problems, and as we age that risk increases.   More than 15 million people in the U.S. abuse or overuse alcohol, and a shockingly-large percentage of those - over 90% -- develop fatty livers. The earliest stage of alcohol-related liver disease, alcoholic fatty liver disease results from the deposition of fat in the liver cells. Signs and symptoms may include fatigue, weakness, discomfort in the right upper abdomen and elevated liver enzymes. If you have fatty liver disease you may be able to reverse it by giving up alcohol. If you continue to drink to excess it may progress to alcoholic hepatitis, which is inflammation and mild scarring of the liver, or cirrhosis, a condition in which scar tissue replaces healthy tissue interfering with the liver’s normal function. Although you can’t reverse cirrhosis by abstaining from alcohol you may be able to improve it and prevent further damage.   In addition to liver disease, problems associated with excessive alcohol use include inflammation of the pancreas, weight gain, malnutrition, nervous system damage, osteoporosis, electrolyte imbalances, problems with concentration, elevated blood lipid levels, inflammation of the heart, some cancers, depression and increased suicide risk.   Despite the dangers of too much alcohol, there is a growing body of evidence that there is no harm in having an occasional or even a regular drink. In fact research suggests that moderate drinking – defined as one to three drinks per day for women -- is associated with lower mortality rates (the risk of dying). Especially when the beverage choice is red wine, alcohol is thought to improve heart health, circulation and sociability.   If you want to include alcohol in your diet, moderation is the key. Precede your drink with at least 8 to 16 ounces of water for hydration (alternately sipping a cocktail and glass of water can help you drink less to too). Drinking with a meal can help your body process the alcohol.   Before you decide to add alcohol to your next meal, get the facts about how much and which type of alcohol you should avoid (a great source of info is www.drinkaware.co.uk). Check your wine's ABV (alcohol by volume) to track how strong it is and what percentage of the drink is made up of alcohol. For example, wine with 12% ABV is 12% pure alcohol. Avoid wines with a high ABV percentage of 18% or more to minimize the negative impacts of alcohol in your system.   If you regularly exceed the recommended alcohol intake of 3 drinks per day for women (a drink equates to approximately three regular bottles of standard 5 percent beer) or 14 drinks per week, seek out the advice of a qualified professional.  
  1. Smoking
While smoking once may have made you look or feel cool, today it just makes you look old. Smoking tobacco damages the delicate skin under your eyes, causes unsightly bags; decreases blood flow to the skin, causing premature aging and wrinkles, stains your teeth and fingernails and increases your risk of periodontal disease and subsequent tooth loss.   Inside your body the picture is no prettier. Have you ever seen the pictures comparing the lungs of smokers and non smokers? While the non-smokers’ lungs are vibrant pink or red, the smokers lungs appear charred or are covered with black spots or holes.   The results of smoking’s internal damage can be lung disease, including lung cancer and emphysema; cardiovascular disease, breast cancer, cancers of the gastrointestinal tract, heart disease, stroke and diabetes.   Unless you have spent the last half century in a remote jungle, the dangers of smoking probably come as no surprise to you. What might surprise you is how much quitting can help, and it’s (almost) never too late to reap some of the benefits of kicking butt, so to speak.   Research shows an overwhelming amount of damage to your health can be reversed by quitting. While the greatest benefits in those who stop young (quitting around age 30 reduces the chance of dying from smoking-related diseases by more than 90 percent), if you quit at 50 or 60 you can still reduce your risk of premature death compared to those who continue smoking.   Not only will quitting increase your chances of living longer, it will also bring benefits to the years you gain. And some of those benefits can be felt almost immediately – as many as 20 minutes after you quit.   Consider these benefits according to Partnership for a Tobacco-Free Maine:   Immediately . . . your heart rate and blood pressure will begin to return to normal.   Within a few hours . . . your body’s level of carbon monoxide, which decreases the blood’s ability to carry oxygen, will begin to decline.   Within a few weeks . . . your circulation improves, you produce less phlegm and you cough or wheeze less often; your heart function improves; food tests better; your sense of smell returns to normal; everyday activities no longer leave you out of breath.   Within several months . . . your lung function improves significantly.   In one year . . . your risk of heart disease, heart attack and stroke is cut in half.     In five years. . . your risk for many kind of cancer, including lung, larynx, mouth, stomach, cervix and bladder, decreases. Your risk may now be similar to that of someone who has never smoked.   Within 10 to 15 years . . . your risk of lung disease is decreased; many medical conditions – including cataracts, macular degeneration, thyroid conditions and osteoporosis, are positively affected; medications may work better, making it possible to take to take some in decreased doses.   Quitting smoking can also save you money. Even if you smoke just two packs a week at an average of $6 a pack (the actual price varies greatly depending on the excise tax in the state where your purchase them), you could save $624 next year on the price of cigarettes alone.   If you purchase your own health insurance as opposed to having insurance provided by an employer, you can save far more than that on your insurance premiums.   Under the Affordable Care Act, smokers can be charged up to 50 percent more on their health insurance premiums. That means if a monthly premium would have been $1000 (which sadly is modest policy for a woman in her late 50s ) your premium as a smoker could and additional $500 monthly or an extra $6000 annually.   While nicotine addiction can be one of the toughest addictions to beat, there are plenty of incentives, both health wise and money wise, to give it your best try. And there is help -- in the form of devices, medications and programs –out there for those who seek it. One of benefit of health insurance plans offered on exchanges established by the Affordable Care Act is that they cover smoking cessation treatment with no coinsurance and no copayment. Take advantage while you can and give yourself the gift of better health, a healthier appearance and quite likely a longer life.    
  1. Sun worshipping
If you grew up in the ‘50s or ‘60s your beach or pool gear may have consisted of baby oil and a “double album” (remember those?) covered in foil to intensify the sun’s rays on your face – yikes!   While you likely have weathered skin to show for it, consider yourself fortunate if wrinkles and creases are the only signs of your sun worship.   Exposure to ultraviolet rays in the single most important factor in the development of skin cancers, which can be disfiguring or even deadly.   There are three main types of skin cancer: basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma and melanoma. The prognosis depends largely on the type. Basal cell carcinoma, the most common form of skin cancer, is also the most treatable. Melanoma, the least common, is the most dangerous. Like all cancers, skin cancers are most treatable are least likely to damage the surrounding tissues when found and treated early. While you can’t reverse the effect of all of those years of sunbathing, you can minimize their appearance. More importantly you can take steps to prevent future damage and reduce your risk of developing skin cancers. Trade in your baby oil for a broad spectrum sunscreen and your foil-covered White Album for a wide-brimmed hat.   Avoid the sun during the hours you may have once regarded as peak tanning hours – roughly 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Report any suspicious skin changes – a mole that changes shape or color, a blemish that bleeds and doesn’t heal – to your doctor, and have regular screens by your family doctor or a dermatologist to check for signs or areas that you may have missed. Next to prevention, early detection and treatment is your best defense.  
  1. Skipping screenings
  Speaking of screenings, keeping up with them at every age is important. As a young woman, your recommended screenings consisted for the most part of a Pap test every three years, an annual breast exam to check for lumps and twice yearly dental checkups. But as you age and your risk of different health problems increases, so does the number of different screenings you need. These include mammograms every one to two years starting at age 40, a fasting plasma glucose test (for diabetes) every three years starting at 45, a colonoscopy every 10 years starting at age 50, and a bone density test at age 65. Screenings allow your doctor to check for signs medical problems before they cause you symptom. For most problems the sooner you detect them and start treatment the better the outcome.   Most health insurance policies now cover routine screening tests with no copayment, so there is really no reason not to keep up with them.   To find a complete list of screenings (and immunizations) recommended for women, visit healthywomen.org. Then speak with your doctor about the tests and frequency that are right for you.   http://www.healthywomen.org/content/article/preventive-health-screenings-women

column2: Does Love Really Matter?
column3: Who better to age with than the love of your life? If your mate is also your best friend, even better! Couples that are mutually endowed with long life can benefit from the emotional, mental, physical and financial support that comes from a long-term commitment. Long-term relationships and marriages start out with the best of intentions and are usually defined by romance, passion and commitment. Recognizing that there are distinct stages of growth necessary for a successful marriage may be the ticket to celebrating your golden years together. After settling into the routine of a happy marriage, the reality-of-life stage takes over and personality differences emerge. Couples that get past the usual conflicts that can arise long after exchanging vows tend to focus more on their common ground, and don’t sweat the differences. We all know that marriage is about give and take. A successful commitment also requires trust, honesty and the ability to forgive each other for past mistakes. After decades of surviving through highs and lows, such as sickness, financial concerns, and family conflicts, a relationship built on mutual respect has a solid foundation to succeed through every stage, including the final farewell. Whether you are a newlywed or celebrating your golden anniversary, the basics remain the same. Retirement and marriage doesn’t always sync up as easily as love and marriage did in the beginning of your relationship and may require a period of adjustment. Without proper planning, it can turn into the relationship from hell that ends in divorce court. Give your spouse or significant other the gift of space and time to adjust to a major lifestyle change, such as retirement. Honey-do lists and personal agendas should not define the start of retirement and can certainly wait a few months. Retirement timetables may not always be in total sync, as often one spouse exits the job market several months or years before the other. View the transitions as stair steps to testing the waters and preparing the boat for the dual journey ahead. Avoid the onset of retired husband syndrome, a recognized affliction that can disrupt the daily routine and order in a household and manifest in the form of physical and mental distress for some stay-at-home wives (I am quite sure it applies to stay at home husbands as well!). When spouses are unaccustomed to spending countless hours together, they sometimes encounter gaps in communication and intimacy - two important building blocks of a relationship. This can be exasperated when a husband with decades of bread-winning behind him experiences a dramatic shift in his daily schedule that may leave many weekdays open with no specific destination or reason to venture out of the house. Suddenly thrust into full-time, domestic life, a retired spouse may create additional work just by hanging out, while remaining oblivious to the extra mess he creates in the process, and thereby cause stress levels to rise within the household. Left unchecked, this type of scenario can sometimes lead to illness, conflicts and possible divorce. The Population Bureau reports that “Although older women today are more likely to be married than they were 50 years ago, they are still much less likely to be married than their male counterparts. Among the population ages 65 and older, about three quarters of men, but less than half (44 percent) of women were married in 2010.” With more professional women leaving the active job market than ever before, this trend will probably continue. To avoid the onset of conflict that comes with spending endless days and nights under the same roof, make a plan to share the brunt of domestic chores. Evaluate the household duties, such as yard work, cooking and cleaning to re-distribute lopsided chores that were performed with habitual ease throughout active career schedules, and which may require a revamp to accommodate less-demanding lifestyles and less-nimble bodies. Since retirement is supposed to be fun, take the calendar out once a month to strategize enjoyable activities that give equal consideration to the individuals, as well as combined preferences, and strive to include several family-centered events in the itinerary. Separate vacations once in a while may help ease the confinement of too many hours spent under the same roof together while giving the relationship breathing room to appreciate each other’s absence. The plus side of staying together for a lifetime is immeasurable. Besides offering emotional support through life’s tragedies, including sickness and the death of loved ones, the lingering effects are less painful when shouldered with a spouse. Marriages that stand the test of time through raising families and beyond are positioned to reap the benefits of their long-term commitment. Double-income families create double-income retirement and pension funds which can translate into living upgrades and more frequent travels. By developing a watchdog approach for each other, longevity becomes a mutual goal for long-term success. Develop new habits with a buddy-system approach that keeps you both on track for fitness and diet goals. Watch for early signs of disease that your spouse may not easily notice, such as sleep apnea or other sleep-related disorders, and become pro-active toward each other’s good health. Discuss the changing landscape of the aging process with your spouse to ease the transition for both of you. Communication levels are triggered by sharing quality time and meals together. For instance, breakfast is the perfect setting to mark the day’s beginning, plan trips, discuss current events and offer upbeat, emotional support for personal issues, such as fading eyesight and receding hairlines. It’s an often-held belief that sex is a by-product of a fertile mind. Intimacy comes in many forms, including spooning beneath the blanket and giving each other mutual massages and back rubs. Physical contact keeps couples connected with empathetic hugs and shoulder squeezes that offer unspoken affirmation of the ‘you’re okay – I’m okay’ validation we all appreciate. Aging well together includes a gradual shift in the closeness and intimacy levels that may have once defined your marriage. Love takes on new meaning in later life, including the frequency of lovemaking. Although the fireworks may not go off every night, older couples can still ignite the fires of passion with great satisfaction. To maintain a healthy sex life, sync up your libido with your spouse and go for quality over quantity by arranging romantic trysts in your candlelit bedroom or perhaps by checking into a luxury hotel. Focus on each other’s good qualities and ignore the rest. The key to longevity for most people is to remain happy and optimistic and enjoy the company you keep on a regular basis. Researchers in the Journal of Marriage and Family agree that when the happiness factor is present, basic needs, such as proper sleep and healthy diet become a natural component of couple longevity. Their findings offer proof that couples who don't argue live longer and happier lives. A team-effort approach to a relationship is particularly important in later years. Winning the race to the 100-year finish line requires a relationship tune-up once in a while, since you are both running on the same engine from start to finish.

column2: Lowering the Risk of Disease
column3:
Beyond the obvious reasons for remaining physically active, there’s even more to consider if you are serious about increasing your odds toward longevity. Aerobic exercise can influence whether the genes for heart disease, diabetes, or other illnesses are activated. If one of your parents has had a heart attack, you have a 30% chance of also having one – research tells us a consistent exercise regimen may combat some of those odds. The Center for Disease Control (CDC) has specific guidelines that outline the benefits of physical activity, which includes controlling your weight, reducing your risk of cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, metabolic syndrome (indicated by thickening around the waist), high blood pressure, low HDL cholesterol and high blood sugar. Research shows that lower rates of these conditions are seen with a minimum of between 2 to 2-1/2 hours per week of at least moderate-intensity aerobic activity. And the more physical activity you do, the lower your risk will be. Being physically active also lowers your risk for both colon and breast cancer. Some findings suggest that your risk of endometrial cancer and lung cancer may be also be lowered if you get regular physical activity compared to people who are not active.
Aerobics, muscle-strengthening and bone-strengthening physical activity of at least a moderately-intensity level can slow the loss of bone density that comes with age. Osteoporosis and bone fractures are serious health conditions that can have life-changing negative effects, but your chances can be minimized by committing to at least 120 to 300 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity each week. Include balance and muscle-strengthening activities each week along with moderate-intensity aerobic activity to help reduce your risk of falling. Regular workouts also help with arthritis and other conditions affecting the joints. With across- the-board, positive results, including reduced blood pressure, lower cortisol levels, and increased joint flexibility - which is beneficial for alleviating the chronic pains of arthritis, it’s not a big leap to nickname fitness the fountain of youth. Your brain power can also improve through aerobic exercise – specifically cognitive function such as task completion, selective attention, and memory. Physical activity can also reduce your risk of depression and may enhance regular sleep cycles. Include balance and muscle-strengthening activities each week along with moderate-intensity aerobic activity to help reduce your risk of falling. The bottom line is that exercise and most physical activity can reduce your risk of dying early from major causes of death like heart disease and some cancers If you’re new to exercise or need to adapt a new exercise plan that corresponds with your individual fitness level, it’s important that you choose the right workout that provides the correct balance of stretching, toning, resistance and cardio activities. Check with local community centers and fitness gyms to see what types of classes they offer to complement your fitness level. Start with small steps and don’t try to jump start an engine that may be out of tune. And it can’t be overstated that you should always check with your doctor before beginning an exercise regimen.
